B003UESJIS|4.0|****1/2<br /><br />Watching a Mike Leigh movie is a bit like eavesdropping on the lives and conversations of people we may not know personally but whom we sure do recognize, since we see so much of ourselves reflected in them.  Part of the reason for this is that Leigh always casts his films with actors who look as little like conventional movie stars as one can imagine (Hollywood, please take note).  It's also because the characters he concerns himself with are ordinary middle- and working class folk, many of them middle-aged, who are suddenly waking up to the fact this may indeed be all there is to life - just a series of ruts and dull routines on the inexorable, if sometimes dawdling, march towards impending death.<br /><br />The individuals in Leigh's latest work, \\"Another Year,\\" perfectly fit the bill.  There's Mary (Lesley Manville), a ditzy divorcee who worries she'll never meet the right man, and Ken (Peter Wight), a brooding, lonely, overweight man who feels keenly the loss of his youth; then there's Imelda Staunton in a very small role as a woman trapped in a state of depression so severe she cannot recall a single happy moment in her life.<br /><br />At the core of the film, however, lie Gerri (Ruth Sheen) and Tom (Jim Broadbent), a happily married couple who somehow seem to have come to terms with the realities of life and aging and, thus, serve as pillars of moral strength and emotional stability that others can lean on in times of stress.<br /><br />As the title suggests, the story spans a twelve-month period, with the script divided into four parts, one for each season.  The \\"story,\\" such as it is, is basically a series of social gatherings (including one funeral) in which the characters discuss the day-to-day realities of their lives.  Only Gerri and Tom remain generally reticent, preferring rather to lend an ear and offer advice than to articulate their own views on life and relationships.  As such, they provide a great calming presence both for the other characters and for the audience, and we can see why each of these individuals is emotionally drawn to them.<br /><br />The flawless cast also features Oliver Maltman as Gerri and Tom's thirty-year-old son, Joe; David Bradley as Tom's recently widowed brother, Ronnie; and Martin Savage as Ronnie's ne'er-do-well son, Ronnie.<br /><br />Set in and around London, Leigh's screenplay makes art out of small-talk, as hurting people hide their pain under a veneer of everyday banter and banalities.  And it's only in rare moments that those true feelings rise to the surface and manifest themselves for all to see.  That seems to be the view of life put forth in not just \\"Another Year\\" but in all of Leigh's work.the audience, and we can see why each of these individuals is emotionally drawn to them.       The flawless cast also features Oliver Maltman as Gerri and Tom's thirty-year-old son, Joe; David Bradley as Tom's recently widowed brother, Ronnie; and Martin Savage as Ronnie's ne'er-do-well son, Ronnie.     Set in and around London, Leigh's screenplay makes art out of small-talk, as hurting people hide their pain under a veneer of everyday banter and banalities.    And it's only in rare moments that those true feelings rise to the surface and manifest themselves for all to see.  That seems to be the view of life put forth in not just \\"Another Year\\" but in all of Leigh's work.

B004WKOCP8|4.0|The title of this review is a lyric from the song, \\"Isadore\\", on Incubus' new album, \\"If Not Now, When?\\".  The lyric sums up where Incubus is as a band five years removed since their last album, \\"Light Grenades\\".    Before the release of 'INNW', lead singer Brandon Boyd said/warned fans the album was going to be different from their previous work. Boyd is correct.  Their albums cover features High Wire artist Philippe Petit, which showcases that Incubus is at a point of their career where they are walking that tight rope between their early work (\\"Fungus Amongus\\", \\"S.C.I.E.N.C.E\\", \\"Make Yourself\\") their middle of the road work (\\"Morning View\\" and \\"A Crow Left of the Murder\\") and the path they are heading growing as artists (\\"Light Grenades\\" and now \\"If Not Now, When\\").      the album is simple and subtle but also sounds like Incubus took their favorite elements from previous albums and threw them into a blender: There are small dark brain-wrinkling guitar sounds from \\"A Crow Left of the Murder\\" (the 2nd half of \\"In the Company of Wolves\\"), glimpses of alternative sounds from \\"Morning View\\" and \\"Make Yourself\\" (with the first single \\"Adolescents\\", \\"Thieves\\" and \\"Switchblade\\"), but I'd say the bulk is surfer/trippy/Incubus love songs from \\"Morning View\\" and \\"Light Grenades\\" (with the title track, \\"If Not Now, When\\", \\"Promises, Promises\\", \\"Friends and Lovers\\", \\"Isadore\\", \\"Tomorrow's Food\\") but everything seems to have  a darker shade pulled over them. I'm not saying the album is a downer, it's just when you're used to hearing Incubus pull out the giant guitar riff they turn left and go a more mellow route.  The band still rocks when it's necessary to rock but it's just different, you know?    It's not an album that people are going to say will change the way we will listen to music forever, it sounds like an album a band got together and said this what we want make collectively.  Which should be applauded and not shunned.  Solid album, not their best, not their worst.

0064410935|5.0|After reading Charlotte's Web by E.B. White, I know I would be very excited to use this book in a third grade classroom. The book takes place in a rural town on a farm, and goes through the adventure of a pig named Wilbur and his friends. Wilbur, who was the runt of his litter, makes many friends, most notably, a spider named Charlotte who makes it her mission to save Wilbur from his fate of being butchered. All of the friends Wilbur makes on the farm; the geese, the sheep, and a sneaky rat, each play a vital role in Wilbur's life and ultimately if he is guaranteed to a full and satisfying life as a farm pig. I feel as though this book is full of meaningful morals and is appropriate reading material to be used in a classroom setting. Students can make connections to the text in terms of friendship, animal loving, life and death, and imagination. This book can also be tied to other subjects lessons such as a science lesson on the anatomy and life of spiders. It uses mature vocabulary to describe the parts of a spider, the life span of a spider, and reproduction of spiders. By bringing in a fantasy book for the children, such as Charlotte's Web, children are able to develop and expand their imagination in a fun, safe, and believable manner that is key to social and academic development.

B004EPZ07K|2.0|For those of you wanting a review from a Green Lantern fan, here I go:<br /><br />The film was okay. But just okay. After seeing it, you have to wonder when you're handling an intellectual property revolving around creativity and imagination, why wasn't more of that injected into the project? Was the director just not up to properly conveying just how large-scale this movie could be? Should have they have just threw a bunch of money at Geoff Johns to write the movie instead of getting a bunch of guys together to see if they could imitate what he's done to make Green Lantern so popular over the last several years? Did they not have to budget to do what they should have, which was to break from the superhero staple of a love interest and set this movie almost entirely in space as Hal learns to sling the green?<br /><br />I'm sure the answers to these questions are known to some already or will come out following the film's release, but for whatever reason, I find it hard to imagine a GL fan would say this movie lives up to its potential. Here are some of the reasons why the film missed the mark:<br /><br />  *Blake Lively was positively wooden save for maybe one scene.<br />  *Hal's time exploring the capabilities of the ring and training on Oa was too brief.<br />  *There's no memorable musical score to go along with the character.<br />  *The CGI of organic creatures was off and felt sub-standard, as if whichever company behind it didn't really take pride in their work.<br />  *The relationship between Hal and Sinestro isn't explored enough, and overall Sinestro wasn't given enough screentime, certainly not enough to demonstrate his motivations for doing what he does in the stinger.<br />  *The action was a bit too brief and the big bad is defeated too easily.<br />  *There were no stand-outs acting-wise.<br />  *There's no real personal beef between the main villain and Hal, so there's little emotional weight to their fight.<br /><br />It's certainly disappointing if you're a GL fan and if you realize how much better it could have been if they'd gone a different way with it or gotten the money and creative team to take pride in the movie rather than simply throw a DC superhero movie out there just to show they're making an effort (albeit minimal) in the comic book big screen battle.<br /><br />I wish I could give it a 2.5/5-Star review because this movie was so middle-of-the-road, but the more I think about this movie, the more I realize how disappointing the experience was, when it should be the other way around, so I'm going to have to round down on this one.r it could have been if they'd gone a different way with it or gotten the money and creative team to take pride in the movie rather than simply throw a DC superhero movie out there just to show they're making an effort (albeit minimal) in the comic book big screen battle.    I wish I could give it a 2.5/5-Star review because this movie was so middle-of-the-road, but the more I think about this movie, the more I realize how disappointing the experience was, when it should be the other way around, so I'm going to have to round down on this one.
0425241505|5.0|This is a debut Urban Fantasy series.  I was very pleased with the book.  It was well written and the main character was very believable.  Unlike most cookie cutter UF heroines, Pia was not all powerful and not brave beyond words.  She wasn't certain of anything except her ability to escape.  Her wardrobe wasn't black, black, and more black.  She wasn't a weapons expert, she wasn't a powerful witch, and she didn't magically develop new powers each chapter.  She was a young woman in a situation not of her making who managed to win the heart of the hero and have a happily ever after.      The book is humorous, with scary parts and laugh out loud parts.  I will be reading the next book in the series.
0345522478|5.0|This review is for the entire series, it's outstanding.  no spoilers.    If you know the Tempe, AZ area it will be that much more of a thrill.  The Author is not lying when they say Rula Bula has the best fish and chips.    The series had me hooked from the first 10 pages.
B003Y5H556|3.0|Even the normally excellent Gary Oldman seems a little off in this rather tired semi-remake of the fairy tale, which visits the Twilight and Potter franchises on the way to grandma's house in hopes of spawning a sequel or three. I'm surprised they didn't work a vampire in here somewhere, actually.<br /><br />Oh well. It looks pretty good, though when will \\"winter\\" movies ever realize that real snow comes with frosty breathing, not invisible breaths? They spent enough on CGI here, so follow through already! But good looks do not a fine flick make, and though there are some decent moments here, and not too much bad acting, there's also not very much great acting or great lines or great anything.<br /><br />Late at night while falling asleep, this might be just the ticket. Otherwise, not so much.<br /><br />And geez, 26 clams for this weak effort on BD? Just goes to prove that the real wolves are in the Dark, Dark Woods of Hollywood! Beware, young damsels: they only want your money...

B0025UHKNS|3.0|I have only used this product all of 3 times now.  This product is as expected.  It does what it says it will.  Acquisition of satellites is pretty fast, in my limited experience.  It took probably less than one minute to find satellites today on a sunny day.      The watch itself comes with a plastic strap, but also comes with a velcro strap you can use instead.  Charger comes with a lot of extra adapters, presumably for use in other countries.  When I run, it is not for long distance--a mile here or there.  Doing so, the battery easily lasts days.    The watch is slightly bigger than a normal watch, which is expected.  But given the contours of the watch, it is hardly noticeable.    I am satisfied with the purchase and would buy again.    The only problems I have is that there were more functions than I thought, honestly.  More likely, I didn't read the instructions carefully enough.  I find the functions a little hard to use.  Again, I've only used it 3 times, but I've ONLY ever used it for time and distance.  I do not use other functions.      I did use the heart rate monitor once.  The included strap goes around your chest obviously.  My frame is small - average.  I wear a size 38 suit.  I wore the chest strap at nearly it's tightest configuration, and it fit well.  It looks to expand another foot in circumference.  If that doesn't sound big enough, no worries--it's all elastic and should accommodate most people.  Chest strap includes battery.    However, function was problematic.  Either I'm is poor physical condition or the biometrics I entered were way off.  In any event, the watch annoyingly sounded an alarm the second I started WALKING.  My cardio isn't great, but I'm pretty sure I wasn't exerting myself.  Potentially user error, or the limits of what the watch thought were normal are way off.  I had to deactivate the heart rate monitor for my run, because it would have alarmed the entire time!
B002ZG99TA|5.0|Not a deep thought provoking film but a good watch nonetheless. The film moves along well and the action is believable.
B00501X6YG|4.0|\\"You'll see perpetual change...\\"<br /><br />In 2008, Yes vocalist Jon Anderson found himself ill and unable to tour for quite some time. The remaining band members decided to continue onward, hiring Yes tribute singer (with some prog cred in Canadian band Mystery) Benoit David. Able to capture Anderson's high-vocaled tenor quite well in concert, things went as well as could be hoped for as Yes toured for the next few years. Rick Wakeman had also departed again during this period (for the, um, 5th time), and his son Oliver took over on keyboards.<br /><br />Yes has always been, from the very first departure of Peter Banks in 1970, a revolving door of players. We all have our favorite albums and lineups, but what always baffled me was seeing/hearing comments by various fans who<br />cannot seem to ever accept what is right in front of them, here and now.<br /><br />Maybe I am just less biased, having discovered Yes as recently as 1998, and I wasn't overexposed towards one particular band member or sound. My first Yes albums that I purchased that summer covered the span from the late 60s to the 90s, so I became a pluralist early on.<br /><br />One of my early favorites was Drama. I paid $ 1.99 for an old beat up cassette of it at a used record store, and I'll never forget the first time I heard \\"Into The Lens\\" as I played it in the car. There was so much darkness, sadness, and emotion in the song. At the time, I had no idea who was singing or playing...to me it was just amazing prog music, and I accepted it at face value.<br /><br />I quickly formed an emotional connection to Drama, and while I also loved 90125, Close To The Edge, Talk, and countless other albums, I never understood the absolute rancor and negativity towards it. Especially coming as it does after Tormato (which has far fewer good songs, and perhaps Wakeman's ugliest keyboard tones, and Jon Anderson's weakest singing and lyrics up to that point), I couldn't see how anyone could comparitively dislike it.<br /><br />Everytime I saw Yes tour, I hoped and prayed, but they never played anything from the album (aside from maybe a quick snippet of \\"Tempus Fugit\\" during the \\"Whitefish\\" solo.) I never had the chance to ask Jon Anderson about it, but whenever I would bring it up at band signings to Alan White or Chris Squire, I would get an embarassed grin and some half-mumbled comment. It was like a kid asking for a toy, and a parent saying \\"someday\\", which really was a subtext for \\"never.\\"<br /><br />As luck would have it, not only would Yes start performing Drama material again on recent post-Anderson tours (\\"Machine Messiah\\" and \\"Tempus Fugit\\"), but Oliver Wakeman was unceremoniously dropped, and Geoff Downes -- my favorite keyboard player, Buggle extraordinaire, and Asia flame-keeper -- would rejoin the band for the first time in 30 years.<br /><br />With Drama-era singer Trevor Horn producing (himself famously responsible for producing 90125 and Big Generator in the 80s, which kickstarted Yes into a whole new fanbase), Fly From Here suddenly sounded very exciting...<br /><br />Regarding the split of Anderson and Wakeman...I will always enjoy their music, and their hugely important contributions to Yes. But they alone are not Yes. And quite frankly, much of their solo work bores me. I wish them the best, and I am excited about their project with Trevor Rabin for 2012, but I am objectively critical of their supposedly god-like status in Yes.<br /><br />Wakeman hasn't had a single tasteful keyboard patch since 1972 (his playing is unvarnished thankfully), and Anderson's singing and lyrics (despite many exceptions along the way), hasn't done much for me in almost as long.<br /><br />Now, onto the music...<br /><br />\\"Fly From Here\\" is the album's 20+ minute title track, broken down into smaller sections. Beginning softly (and with a piano motif that almost brings to mind \\"White Car\\"), we launch into \\"Overture\\". Perhaps the highlight of the album for me, this is Yes at their epic best, firing on all cylinders. Piano is mixed with sighing 80s-style synth, and reverbed triggered drum effects create a forward movement as Chris Squire's chunky, thumping bass keeps a steady pulse. Right away it is clear that Trevor Horn's production has treated us to the best-sounding Yes album in quite some years, as far as clarity and space between instruments and vocals.<br /><br />This intro smoothly transitions into \\"We Can Fly\\". Written in 1980 by Trevor Horn and Geoff Downes just prior to the Drama sessions, it was demoed and played live on the subsequent tour. Heard for many years on various bootleg recordings (and finally given an official release in 2005 on the boxed set The Word Is Live), it was introduced onstage as being \\"on the followup to Drama\\", which was ostensibly planned for 1981. This Yes lineup dissapated, however, and interestingly enough...30 years later...things have come full circle, and you could very well describe Fly From Here as that followup album, seeing as how it has 4/5ths of the Drama lineup, and with Trevor Horn as a primary influence in the writing and recording.<br /><br />\\"We Can Fly\\" has beautiful keyboard and piano melodies, and the harmony vocals are gorgeous. New vocalist Benoit David asserts himself wonderfully, somewhat surprisingly sounding less like Jon Anderson and a bit more like Trevor Horn (more Parallels!)<br /><br />\\"Sad Night at the Airfield\\" (previously heard as a shorter demo by The Buggles) begins with some somber acoustic guitar by Steve Howe. It explodes with melody as the line \\"...Of air, that clouds in the night as we breathe.\\" This is one of the most gorgeous moments on the album, as the old Drama elements resurface again (Squire's bass, and Downes' old Fairlight keyboard.)  This section is the highlight of the album for me, as the next verse brings everything a step higher, Howe joins in on pedal steel, and the vocals and keyboards reach a crescendo of esquisite beauty.<br /><br />This is one of those stamped and trademarked \\"Yes moments\\", akin to the musical peaks found in \\"And You And I\\", \\"The Revealing Science of God\\", \\"Endless Dream\\", or \\"Awaken.\\"<br /><br />We return to the original piano motif as we explode into \\"Madman at the Screens\\", which is basically the \\"Overture\\" extended with more instrumentation and lyrics. The music is joyful, bouncy, and dramatic, as it moves between the dynamics of darkness and beauty. The overall structure is very pop-oriented, and the little xylophone-type keyboard tones unconciously make me recall the best moments of ABBA. Near the end of the song, some classic Hammond organ joins in. And is that a Taurus bass pedal I hear?<br /><br />\\"Bumpy Ride\\" comes next, perhaps the most \\"oddball\\" moment in the suite. This has a strong Howe influence in the bouncy, quirky playing and guitar tone, and subtly reminds me of something that might have been heard on his<br />first two solo albums. A fun mostly instrumental segment, it again moves from light to shade and back again. I'm very much also reminded of a sound that could have come from the Tormato album.<br /><br />With a sudden changeover (almost too unexpected and odd, IMO) \\"We Can Fly - Reprise\\" ends the song suite as it began. Although not the most climactic ending on a Yes epic, it gets the job done.<br /><br />\\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a good mid-tempo ballad, which grows on me more with each listen. Chris Squire handles the lead on this, and his vocals have always been underrated in the Yes recipe, as far as I'm concerned. This song is reminiscent of material on his 1975 solo album Fish Out Of Water, again recalling the past...<br /><br />\\"Life On A Film Set\\" is classic symphonic prog. The beginning of the song is highly similiar to any number of acoustic ballads to be found on the early albums by Yes, King Crimson, or ELP. The production and sound gets<br />more dense as it moves forward, moving from moody balladry to bouncy and joyful moments. When I sit back and objectively pay attention to all of the song elements, it really captures the Yes that I know and love so<br />well. A bouncy, fun, beautifully-layered song as only they could do it.<br /><br />\\"Hour of Need\\" is classic Steve Howe again, featuring his Porteguese guitar, which brings back memories of \\"I've Seen All Good People\\", \\"Wonderous Stories\\", \\"Sketches In The Sun\\", and \\"Nine Voices.\\" The harmony vocals are (again) gorgeous, and the moog keyboards join in tastefully here and there. This is Classic Yes, in the wonderful tradition of Fragile and Going For The One.<br /><br />\\"Solitaire\\" is an acoustic guitar piece, this time featuring Steve by himself. Howe's solo moments are always tasteful, refined, quirky, and reflective, and this one is no exception. This is very much in the same<br />ouvre as \\"Mood For A Day\\" and \\"Masquerade.\\"<br /><br />\\"Into The Storm\\" features songwriting contributions from all band members, and again with the bubbly bass guitar, piano, harmonies, and keyboards, sounds like something from the 1977-80 period. An upbeat, positive ending to the album.<br /><br />As far as individual contributions, I would say that Squire's bass-playing and singing is top-notch as it has been for ages, Steve Howe sounds very refined, fiery and confidant (see what health food and meditation can do for you, kids?), and Geoff Downes does a good simple job of bringing in his poppy, quirky Buggles keyboards, while still retaining the classic Yes motifs of mini-moog, Hammond, and mellotron. Only Alan White (on drums) sounds a little subdued, but he has a few interesting textural shuffles and grooves.<br /><br />Overall, I think it is fair to say that Fly From Here is the (overall) best Yes album since 90125, and slightly edges out ahead of The Ladder, which (especially in retrospect) was quite amazing itself. It certainly sounds like the followup to Drama (in some parallel universe 1981.) Let's call it Drama 2.0.<br /><br />\\"One word can bring you 'round...changes.\\"<br /><br />Yes will always be different things to different people. Its overall dynamic is sort of like a diamond...there are a lot of rough edges and dark spots, but turn it around slightly and you will see joyful, crystalline moments as well. To me, it's always been about the message of positivity, relationships, love, and change. Being truly progressive; trying new things, new approaches, new styles. Mixing some Indian raga with some country music. Some techno-pop with some arena rock. Some church choirs with some classical granduer.<br /><br />I am just extremely tired of how the band and their legacy have carried onward through the years. The group spent so many years chasing hit singles after the success of \\"Owner of a Lonely Heart\\", and became blinded by management, technology, and money. Relations broke down, factions formed, and no one seemed to know how to capture the original band spirit of five guys sitting in a living room or barn, and just brainstorming and writing some music together on a set of drums, piano and acoustic guitar. Yes unconciously stopped believing in themselves, and the fans followed suit. When in doubt, keep it simple. And just do it.<br /><br />Fly From Here is a fantastic album, and a great reminder of sounds and places that remind you of a distant past, while still looking over that distant horizon. Remember...We can fly...God\\", \\"Endless Dream\\", or \\"Awaken.\\"    We return to the original piano motif as we explode into \\"Madman at the Screens\\", which is basically the \\"Overture\\" extended with more instrumentation and lyrics. The music is joyful, bouncy, and dramatic, as it moves between the dynamics of darkness and beauty. The overall structure is very pop-oriented, and the little xylophone-type keyboard tones unconciously make me recall the best moments of ABBA. Near the end of the song, some classic Hammond organ joins in. And is that a Taurus bass pedal I hear?    \\"Bumpy Ride\\" comes next, perhaps the most \\"oddball\\" moment in the suite. This has a strong Howe influence in the bouncy, quirky playing and guitar tone, and subtly reminds me of something that might have been heard on his   first two solo albums. A fun mostly instrumental segment, it again moves from light to shade and back again. I'm very much also reminded of a sound that could have come from the Tormato album.    With a sudden changeover (almost too unexpected and odd, IMO) \\"We Can Fly - Reprise\\" ends the song suite as it began. Although not the most climactic ending on a Yes epic, it gets the job done.    \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a good mid-tempo ballad, which grows on me more with each listen. Chris Squire handles the lead on this, and his vocals have always been underrated in the Yes recipe, as far as I'm concerned. This song is reminiscent of material on his 1975 solo album Fish Out Of Water, again recalling the past...    \\"Life On A Film Set\\" is classic symphonic prog. The beginning of the song is highly similiar to any number of acoustic ballads to be found on the early albums by Yes, King Crimson, or ELP. The production and sound gets   more dense as it moves forward, moving from moody balladry to bouncy and joyful moments. When I sit back and objectively pay attention to all of the song elements, it really captures the Yes that I know and love so   well. A bouncy, fun, beautifully-layered song as only they could do it.    \\"Hour of Need\\" is classic Steve Howe again, featuring his Porteguese guitar, which brings back memories of \\"I've Seen All Good People\\", \\"Wonderous Stories\\", \\"Sketches In The Sun\\", and \\"Nine Voices.\\" The harmony vocals are (again) gorgeous, and the moog keyboards join in tastefully here and there. This is Classic Yes, in the wonderful tradition of Fragile and Going For The One.    \\"Solitaire\\" is an acoustic guitar piece, this time featuring Steve by himself. Howe's solo moments are always tasteful, refined, quirky, and reflective, and this one is no exception. This is very much in the same   ouvre as \\"Mood For A Day\\" and \\"Masquerade.\\"    \\"Into The Storm\\" features songwriting contributions from all band members, and again with the bubbly bass guitar, piano, harmonies, and keyboards, sounds like something from the 1977-80 period. An upbeat, positive ending to the album.    As far as individual contributions, I would say that Squire's bass-playing and singing is top-notch as it has been for ages, Steve Howe sounds very refined, fiery and confidant (see what health food and meditation can do for you, kids?), and Geoff Downes does a good simple job of bringing in his poppy, quirky Buggles keyboards, while still retaining the classic Yes motifs of mini-moog, Hammond, and mellotron. Only Alan White (on drums) sounds a little subdued, but he has a few interesting textural shuffles and grooves.    Overall, I think it is fair to say that Fly From Here is the (overall) best Yes album since 90125, and slightly edges out ahead of The Ladder, which (especially in retrospect) was quite amazing itself. It certainly sounds like the followup to Drama (in some parallel universe 1981.) Let's call it Drama 2.0.    \\"One word can bring you 'round...changes.\\"    Yes will always be different things to different people. Its overall dynamic is sort of like a diamond...there are a lot of rough edges and dark spots, but turn it around slightly and you will see joyful, crystalline moments as well. To me, it's always been about the message of positivity, relationships, love, and change. Being truly progressive; trying new things, new approaches, new styles. Mixing some Indian raga with some country music. Some techno-pop with some arena rock. Some church choirs with some classical granduer.     I am just extremely tired of how the band and their legacy have carried onward through the years. The group spent so many years chasing hit singles after the success of \\"Owner of a Lonely Heart\\", and became blinded by management, technology, and money. Relations broke down, factions formed, and no one seemed to know how to capture the original band spirit of five guys sitting in a living room or barn, and just brainstorming and writing some music together on a set of drums, piano and acoustic guitar. Yes unconciously stopped believing in themselves, and the fans followed suit. When in doubt, keep it simple. And just do it.    Fly From Here is a fantastic album, and a great reminder of sounds and places that remind you of a distant past, while still looking over that distant horizon. Remember...We can fly...
B002ZG99QS|4.0|As with many sequels this one falls a little short of the original. Although the special effects have been upgraded, this is no more than the minimum expected. That being said, it is still an enjoyable film that holds the viewer's attention.

A fun mostly instrumental segment, it again moves from light to shade and back again. I'm very much also reminded of a sound that could have come from the Tormato album.<br /><br />With a sudden changeover (almost too unexpected and odd, IMO) \\"We Can Fly - Reprise\\" ends the song suite as it began. Although not the most climactic ending on a Yes epic, it gets the job done.<br /><br />\\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a good mid-tempo ballad, which grows on me more with each listen. Chris Squire handles the lead on this, and his vocals have always been underrated in the Yes recipe, as far as I'm concerned. This song is reminiscent of material on his 1975 solo album Fish Out Of Water, again recalling the past...<br /><br />\\"Life On A Film Set\\" is classic symphonic prog. The beginning of the song is highly similiar to any number of acoustic ballads to be found on the early albums by Yes, King Crimson, or ELP. The production and sound gets<br />more dense as it moves forward, moving from moody balladry to bouncy and joyful moments. When I sitback and objectively pay attention to all of the song elements, it really captures the Yes that I know and love so<br />well. A bouncy, fun, beautifully-layered song as only they could do it.<br /><br />\\"Hour of Need\\" is classic Steve Howe again, featuring his Porteguese guitar, which brings back memories of \\"I've Seen All Good People\\", \\"Wonderous Stories\\", \\"Sketches In The Sun\\", and \\"Nine Voices.\\" The harmony vocals are (again) gorgeous, and the moog keyboards join in tastefully here and there. This is Classic Yes, in the wonderful tradition of Fragile and Going For The One.<br /><br />\\"Solitaire\\" is an acoustic guitar piece, this time featuring Steve by himself. Howe's solo moments are always tasteful, refined, quirky, and reflective, and this one is no exception. This is very much in the same<br />ouvre as \\"Mood For A Day\\" and \\"Masquerade.\\"<br /><br />\\"Into The Storm\\" features songwriting contributions from all band members, and again with the bubbly bass guitar, piano, harmonies, and keyboards, sounds like something from the 1977-80 period. An upbeat, positive ending to the album.<br /><br />As far as individual contributions, I would say that Squire's bass-playing and singing is top-notch as it has been for ages, Steve Howe sounds very refined, fiery and confidant (see what health food and meditation can do for you, kids?), and Geoff Downes does a good simple job of bringing in his poppy, quirky Buggles keyboards, while still retaining the classic Yes motifs of mini-moog, Hammond, and mellotron. Only Alan White (on drums) sounds a little subdued, but he has a few interesting textural shuffles and grooves.<br /><br />Overall, I think it is fair to say that Fly From Here is the (overall) best Yes album since 90125, and slightly edges out ahead of The Ladder, which (especially in retrospect) was quite amazing itself. It certainly sounds like the followup to Drama (in some parallel universe 1981.) Let's call it Drama 2.0.<br /><br />\\"One word can bring you 'round...changes.\\"<br /><br />Yes will always be different things to different people. Its overall dynamic is sort of like a diamond...there are a lot of rough edges and dark spots, but turn it around slightly and you will see joyful, crystalline moments as well. To me, it's always been about the message of positivity, relationships, love, and change. Being truly progressive; trying new things, new approaches, new styles. Mixing some Indian raga with some country music. Some techno-pop with some arena rock. Some church choirs with some classical granduer.<br /><br />I am just extremely tired of how the band and their legacy have carried onward through the years. The group spent so many years chasing hit singles after the success of \\"Owner of a Lonely Heart\\", and became blinded by management, technology, and money. Relations broke down, factions formed, and no one seemed to know how to capture the original band spirit of five guys sitting in a living room or barn, and just brainstorming and writing some music together on a set of drums, piano and acoustic guitar. Yes unconciously stopped believing in themselves, and the fans followed suit. When in doubt, keep it simple. And just do it.<br /><br />Fly From Here is a fantastic album, and a great reminder of sounds and places that remind you of a distant past, while still looking over that distant horizon. Remember...We can fly...ndless Dream\\", or \\"Awaken.\\"    We return to the original piano motif as we explode into \\"Madman at the Screens\\", which is basically the \\"Overture\\" extended with more instrumentation and lyrics. The music is joyful, bouncy, and dramatic, as it moves between the dynamics of darkness and beauty. The overall structure is very pop-oriented, and the little xylophone-type keyboard tones unconciously make me recall the best moments of ABBA. Near the end of the song, some classic Hammond organ joins in. And is that a Taurus bass pedal I hear?    \\"Bumpy Ride\\" comes next, perhaps the most \\"oddball\\" moment in the suite. This has a strong Howe influence in the bouncy, quirky playing and guitar tone, and subtly reminds me of something that might have been heard on his  first two solo albums. A fun mostly instrumental segment, it again moves from light to shade and back again. I'm very much also reminded of a sound that could have come from the Tormato album.    With a sudden changeover (almost too unexpected and odd, IMO) \\"We Can Fly - Reprise\\" ends the song suite as it began. Although not the most climactic ending on a Yes epic, it gets the job done.    \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a good mid-tempo ballad, which grows on me more with each listen. Chris Squire handles the lead on this, and his vocals have always been underrated in the Yes recipe, as far as I'm concerned. This song is reminiscent of material on his 1975 solo album Fish Out Of Water, again recalling the past...    \\"Life On A Film Set\\" is classic symphonic prog. The beginning of the song is highly similiar to any number of acoustic ballads to be found on the early albums by Yes, King Crimson, or ELP. The production and sound gets  more dense as it moves forward, moving from moody balladry to bouncy and joyful moments. When I sit back and objectively pay attention to all of the song elements, it really captures the Yes that I know and love so  well. A bouncy, fun, beautifully-layered song as only they could do it.    \\"Hour of Need\\" is classic Steve Howe again, featuring his Porteguese guitar, which brings back memories of \\"I've Seen All Good People\\", \\"Wonderous Stories\\", \\"Sketches In The Sun\\", and \\"Nine Voices.\\" The harmony vocals are (again) gorgeous, and the moog keyboards join in tastefully here and there. This is Classic Yes, in the wonderful tradition of Fragile and Going For The One.    \\"Solitaire\\" is an acoustic guitar piece, this time featuring Steve by himself. Howe's solo moments are always tasteful, refined, quirky, and reflective, and this one is no exception. This is very much in the same  ouvre as \\"Mood For A Day\\" and \\"Masquerade.\\"    \\"Into The Storm\\" features songwriting contributions from all band members, and again with the bubbly bass guitar, piano, harmonies, and keyboards, sounds like something from the 1977-80 period. An upbeat, positive ending to the album.    As far as individual contributions, I would say that Squire's bass-playing and singing is top-notch as it has been for ages, Steve Howe sounds very refined, fiery and confidant (see what health food and meditation can do for you, kids?), and Geoff Downes does a good simple job of bringing in his poppy, quirky Buggles keyboards, while still retaining the classic Yes motifs of mini-moog, Hammond, and mellotron. Only Alan White (on drums) sounds a little subdued, but he has a few interesting textural shuffles and grooves.    Overall, I think it is fair to say that Fly From Here is the (overall) best Yes album since 90125, and slightly edges out ahead of The Ladder, which (especially in retrospect) was quite amazing itself. It certainly sounds like the followup to Drama (in some parallel universe 1981.) Let's call it Drama 2.0.    \\"One word can bring you 'round...changes.\\"    Yes will always be different things to different people. Its overall dynamic is sort of like a diamond...there are a lot of rough edges and dark spots, but turn it around slightly and you will see joyful, crystalline moments as well. To me, it's always been about the message of positivity, relationships, love, and change. Being truly progressive; trying new things, new approaches, new styles. Mixing some Indian raga with some country music. Some techno-pop with some arena rock. Some church choirs with some classical granduer.    I am just extremely tired of how the band and their legacy have carried onward through the years. The group spent so many years chasing hit singles after the success of \\"Owner of a Lonely Heart\\", and became blinded by management, technology, and money. Relations broke down, factions formed, and no one seemed to know how to capture the original band spirit of five guys sitting in a living room or barn, and just brainstorming and writing some music together on a set of drums, piano and acoustic guitar. Yes unconciously stopped believing in themselves, and the fans followed suit. When in doubt, keep it simple. And just do it.    Fly From Here is a fantastic album, and a great reminder of sounds and places that remind you of a distant past, while still looking over that distant horizon. Remember...We can fly...
B0042816YK|3.0|Much has been said about this movie not being nearly as good as the book, and that is all nonsense.  The book is a monologue and since when have you gone to the cinema to see a movie with almost no dialogue, just one person talking?  Would you really want to watch a woman in the midst of a nervous breakdown, constantly screaming and weeping, all \\"ME ME ME, WHY ME\\"?  Most folks would not, and would say she needed to get her act together, which is what the book is about.  The movie hardly mentions that part.   Some books, like \\"Room With A View\\" make it to the screen almost entirely intact and watching the (Merchant Ivory) movie is like seeing the beloved book brought to life.  Other books, like \\"Under The Tuscan Sun\\" end up with a movie that bears no resemblance to the book, because the book wasn't that good to begin with.  \\"Eat Pray Love\\" is something else.  Bits and pieces of the book are cherry picked and a movie was made, with characters invented to give a home to parts of the monologue now repurposed as dialogue.  Almost nothing in the movie happens in the way it was written in the book, but we get an entertaining romantic comedy with some spiritual mumbo-jumbo, and without all the gut wrenching self loathing, and mental melt down.      We also get some fairly gorgeous cinematography, particularly in the Italy and Bali sections.      Unfortunately, it seems that quite a bit of the film ended up on the editing room floor which makes some parts of the film seem like they need a bit more explaining, something that is far more clear if you've read the book, but not essential to the enjoyment of this film.    I have now enjoyed the book, and will still enjoy the movie as I found it, a romantic comedy/a \\"chick flick\\".  To all those who are hysterical that we didn't get a film about a neurotic, screaming, control freak alternately discovering the pleasures of the world and how to actually live in it I say, Bah.  Bah!

1451629184|5.0|The first thing you need to know about Jaycee Dugard's book, is it is indeed a very difficult thing to read. It is a beautifully written, pull no punches account of the 18 years she spent in captivity with a very sick man, Phillip Garrido.    In a note from the author at the beginning of the book, Dugard explains that she wrote the book to attempt to convey the overwhelming confusion she endured during her years in captivity and to begin to unravel the damage that was done to she and her family. She chronicles her experience with brutal honesty. She writes about missing her mother and worrying that she will never see her again. Her dependence upon her kidnapper grows the more he isolates her from the world. For long periods of time he was the only other human being that she saw.    Before I bought the book, I wished that Amazon would list the Table of Contents, so here it is for you:    Author's Note  Introduction  The Taking  Stolen  The Secret Backyard  Alone in a Strange Place  The First Time  First Kitty  The First \\"Run\\"  Nancy  Easter: Phillip on an Island  Christmas  Learning I Was Pregnant  Driving to a Trailer  Waiting for Baby  Taking Care of a Baby  Sarge  Second Baby  The Starting of Printing for Less  Birth of Second Baby  Raising the Girls in the Backyard  Nancy Becomes \\"Mom\\"  Pretending to Be a Family  Cats  Surviving  Discovery and Reunion  Firsts for Me   Milestones  The Difficult Parts of Life  Finding Old Friends  Therapeutic healing  Meeting with Nancy  Therapeutic Healing with a Twist    As you can tell from the Table of Contents, she spares no detail. You witness her physical and psychological transformation from a scared child held against her will to a woman who bears his children and runs a business with him until she is discovered. This truly is an exploration of her past. As profound as this book is in its horrific detail, it is not a triumphant, feel-good story. Other than her rescue, don't expect many warm fuzzies from this one.    If Jaycee's book interests you, [[ASIN:0061543667 I Love Yous Are for White People: A Memoir (P.S.)]] is another you'll undoubtedly want to read. Amazing to see people triumph over such adversity, and retell their stories so brilliantly.

1451629184|5.0|*****<br />Jaycee Dugard's memoir of her life and her kidnapping, her torture, abuse and 18 year captivity, is important on so many levels.<br /><br />At one level, this is a young woman's attempt to tell the details of her story and to regain her voice and her power. She is grateful to be alive, to be safe, and to have her daughters, her mom, her sister. Her story in its entirety--the actual details--go far beyond Diane Sawyer's two hour ABC news special, so if you've watched that (as I did), there is much, much more here. And again, the details are what add depth and so poignantly reveal how Jaycee FELT in the different circumstances she found herself in, all of which she had no or little control over. She learned how to survive and how to live as meaningful a life as possible (although this was very hard with rape, neglect, and abuse of all sorts). She did it, though, and has triumphed--with the help of many people, good therapists, and experiences such as equine therapy. All of this is described in the book.<br /><br />Jaycee describes her daily concerns, her profound loneliness, and how she longed for things like a toothbrush, a bath, a toilet, to see the outdoors. She describes how her captor bonded her to to him, with him even trying to give her torture meaning and purpose by telling her it saved him from doing things like that to other little girls. And how great a \\"sex slave\\" she was. Her abuser's horrible \\"crank runs\\" --long days of her enduring various types of rape while her abuser was high and sleepless on crank. How after her baby was born, her abuser prayed that he'd never \\"hurt his child\\", which she knew meant \\"rape his child\\". Despite all of this horror, Jaycee's beautiful spirit shines through. So this is a hard book, and a book not for children because of all of the graphic details, but an important book for everyone else to read. None of the sexual details are gratuitous, but helpful and moving in understanding how a young girl saw her torment.<br /><br />And at another level, this is a tale of hope and inspiration, a tale of Jaycee's tenacious spirit and how she survived. It can provide inspiration to all of us who deal on a daily basis with challenges and trials, probably none anywhere near as terrible as Jaycee's. Her spirit and will to survive are admirable and so worth reading about. She wants to inspire people and to encourage them to have hope in difficult circumstances.<br /><br />And at yet another level, I hope that this memoir leads to changes in how the criminal justice system monitors sex offenders. So much needs to be reformed. I hope that this book, and those of us who read it, will help to facilitate and even demand needed change.<br /><br />Lastly, Jaycee wants to inspire people to speak up and take action when they suspect, intuit, guess--that something may be wrong. It was two women officers who ended Jaycee's captivity--two women who trusted their intuition that something was \\"off\\" after seeing her and then acted to investigate and follow through.<br /><br />The author's trust and hope, though betrayed again and again, still live on. This is a fascinating and riveting read about the human spirit, a book you'll have a hard time putting down. It is told in the present tense, so that you feel as though you're there with Jaycee. The book is organized into chapters in chronological order; at the end of each chapter she writes her reflections now that she is safe as an adult. In the Kindle edition, there are black and white pictures of Jaycee and pictures of her journal pages, not just the text of the hardcover.<br /><br />Highly recommended.<br />*****level, this is a tale of hope and inspiration, a tale of Jaycee's tenacious spirit and how she survived. It can provide inspiration to all of us who deal on a daily basis with challenges and trials, probably none anywhere near as terrible as Jaycee's. Her spirit and will to survive are admirable and so worth reading about. She wants to inspire people and to encourage them to have hope in difficult circumstances.     And at yet another level, I hope that this memoir leads to changes in how the criminal justice system monitors sex offenders. So much needs to be reformed. I hope that this book, and those of us who read it, will help to facilitate and even demand needed change.     Lastly, Jaycee wants to inspire people to speak up and take action when they suspect, intuit, guess--that something may be wrong. It was two women officers who ended Jaycee's captivity--two women who trusted their intuition that something was \\"off\\" after seeing her and then acted to investigate and follow through.     The author's trust and hope, though betrayed again and again, still live on. This is a fascinating and riveting read about the human spirit, a book you'll have a hard time putting down. It is told in the present tense, so that you feel as though you're there with Jaycee. The book is organized into chapters in chronological order; at the end of each chapter she writes her reflections now that she is safe as an adult. In the Kindle edition, there are black and white pictures of Jaycee and pictures of her journal pages, not just the text of the hardcover.    Highly recommended.  *****

B004YTGRMI|5.0|On Lifes Rich Pageant, R.E.M. started to make the move from their college-rock underground sound to a more commercially accessible one. They did this successfully without compromising any of their integrity. The songs still have that classic R.E.M. jangle-guitar sound, but they started to experiment with other sounds (like the banjo on \\"I Believe\\" & accordian on \\"Swan Song H\\") as well as becoming more socially and political conscious with their lyrics. Also, most noticable was that Michael Stipe's vocals were higher in the mix instead of being muddy and buried as on previous releases. \\"Fall On Me\\" best typifies the changes as the song is about the effects of acid rain, but is the most radio-friendly song they had made up to that point. \\"Flowers Of Guatemala\\", \\"Hyena\\", \\"I Believe\\" & \\"Swan Song H\\" are among the best R.E.M. has ever done. The album is like a classic novel with the songs being like its chapters. From the opening chapter of \\"Begin The Begin\\" to the epilogue of \\"Superman\\", R.E.M. takes us on a wondereous journey that makes you want to keep going back and explore more carefully with each listen. It's hard to belive that this album is turning 25 years old, but it is nice to see that the band is celebrating it's release.  R.E.M. has made better sellers and more critically praised albums, but none are better than this one in my mind.  The bonus disk is a treasure trove of great alternate versions of almost every song the original album as well as the first recording of \\"Bad Day\\" which would appear on a greatest hits album.

OK, I thought, some of those were funny. Then two chapters later we get another long section about her looks and her flat, manly feet.  OK, a bit irritating (I mean, who seriously cares about feet?) but I'll go with it.  Now I'm in the middle of the part about celebrity photo shoots which, you guessed it, is mainly about how she, hilariously, doesn't fit into clothes meant for models.  Seriously, I've had enough.  Firstly, Tina Fey is a damned good-looking woman, so it's just insulting to genuine gargoyles for her to be claiming she's a troll in a looks-obsessed industry. Secondly, it's clearly Tina Fey herself that is looks-obsessed - I can't imagine Paris Hilton devoting this much time to talking about her body. If you spend this much of your book describing your feet - even in a self-deprecating way - you need to re-examine your priorities.  As for the other, non-body related stuff, it principally consists of (a) describing collegues - comedians and actors - as geniuses (in true \\"luvvies\\" fashion) and (b) sticking it to the odd anonymous nobody that said something vaguely insulting to her when she was working at The Second City in Chicago twenty years ago.  There are a lot of reviews saying that this book doesn't reveal much about Tina Fey - I disagree - I think it reveals a great deal.  Here is a fundamentally shallow person. Still, she makes funny TV, so I'll just continue enjoying 30 Rock and give the rest of the book a miss.
B001E45XT4|3.0|I love the quality of sound and mic that I got from this product. When I first got it I had to spend about 20 minutes in audio settings to tweak the mic as it is too sensitive and needed to be adjusted so that it's not transmitting every sound in the house. Unfortunately it seems that after using the mic day in day out pulling it out from its little resting place is damaging the cord as the mic has stopped working. Except for sparse moments when the damaged wires can be fiddled into a position where they might touch again within the headset where now it has the mic in a awkward position where it's more static than voice. Keep in mind I have only had it for a year and I might have used it for a few hours a day so I'm sadden that such a great product would have such a short lifespan. I even bought a second one when it went on sale and unfortunately the audio is cutting out on this one with lots of static and or audio only in one ear, again after owning it for only a year with moderate use. As much as I enjoy the quality of the recording and audio while it works, I don't think I'll buy a third one. I don't think a headset should be an annual purchase, especially one as expensive as this.

B004XES1U0|4.0|What does Fly From Here sound like? Does it sound like Close to the Edge, Relayer, Going for the One, Drama, or 90125? Does it matter? To fans of Jon Anderson and/or Rick Wakeman and/or the \\"classic line-up of the such and such era\\" it probably does matter, however these fans will most likely not be swayed no matter what. Due to the time wasting arguments and squabbling between the members of Yes and the even more nasty squabbling between the fans about the viability of a Jon Anderson and/or Rick Wakeman-less Yes on fan sites and message boards, not to mention cancelled tours such as the More Drama or the Close to the Edge and Back tour, I was becoming weary of being a Yes fan. I just did not think they had it in them for another recording no matter who was playing on it and even if they did, I doubted they would ever get it together to make it a reality or even moreso that I would want to listen to it.     And now we have Fly From Here. As stated above, when asked \\"What does FFH sound like?\\", well, it sounds like Yes in 2011! People will hear snippets of various line-ups and recordings (I hear snippets of Drama, a bit of 90125 and Big Generator, with some of the pop sensibilities of Asia). Once you listen to FFH, you will come up with your own ideas of what era/line-up it reminds you of.     Although FFH does not achieve the musical or popular heights of either the Fragile/CTTE or 90125 era, it delivers a sturdy set of quality songs that comprise a thoughtful, consistent offering that I had no reason to expect to be as good as it is. The FFH suite (based on the Drama-era song Fly From Here) is cohesive if a bit lacking in instrumental virtuosity as the instrumental fireworks of the 70s era (remember 'Soundchaser'?) are not as present on this cd. Instead of striving for who can outdo each other with instrumental virtuosity within a song (and stepping all over each other in the process), the emphasis is on economy (IMO none of the songs or musical ideas overstay their welcome), and the melodic flow of the songs themselves. Part I 'We Can Fly From Here' is as gorgeous as anything produced by the band from 1997 onwards. All of the themes in the Overture (note the snare drum rolls of reminiscent of 'White Car' midway through), are revisited throughout the suite and the lyrics about aviation and relationships make a nice theme to base this musical suite around.     Strangely enough, the songs I find myself gravitating the most towards on FFH are the straightforward, soothing pop of both 'The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be' co-written by Chris Squire and 'Hour of Need' written by Steve Howe as they just sound 'different' to me for some reason. In a sense, some might say these songs are representative of the pop sensibilities of the latter-day reunited Asia being interpreted in a Yes context. No matter, I just hear some lyrically thoughtful compositions with some gorgeous chord progressions and melodies. These songs are not the pop found on 90125 as they tend towards a current, mature MOR sound more than 80s pop (or even 70s progressive rock for that matter) which leads me to wonder what else Steve and Chris could have come up with for Yes in this setting. 'Life on a Film Set' was written by the Buggles themselves, and although the first half of this song plods along a bit slowly, the second half is a joyous dance. Steve's solo piece 'Solitaire' while skillfully and very tastily executed lacks some of the energy of his other solo pieces such as 'Second Initial' or 'Sketches In the Sun' (not to mention 'The Clap' and 'Mood for a Day').     The dipthong bass pedal sound from 'On The Silent Wings Of Freedom' from Tormato makes an appearance on 'Into the Storm', the cd's energetic closer that may remind some of 'Tempus Fugit'. Benoit David, instead of trying to be Jon Anderson, actually finds his own voice within the band and if comparisons must be made, Benoit sounds more like Trevor Horn than Jon. Speaking of Trevor Horn, getting him to produce this cd (as well as having Geoff Downes rejoin the band) was nothing short of genius. Trevor's production gives the songs room to breathe while adding some polish and sheen without being overproduced.     If this is to be Yes' last recording, then this is a very worthy effort as such (well, for me at least). Although there might not be the one or more songs that just 'blow you away' on the first listen of this album, I will trade that for the consistency, economy, maturity, and thoughtfulness of FFH's set of songs. If you are able to embrace the concept of Yesmusic being more than the specific line-up of who plays on a specific recording in a specific time period, hopefully you will too!
B004H4XLRE|3.0|My grandson is a super cars fan, he has approx 200 different cars and I got his this for his b-day.  He loved it.  Would recommend it.

B0050VI5SI|5.0|One of the earlier reviews here was title \\"Can't believe I like it!\\".  I know exactly what that person meant!  This album doesn't really line up with anything else in my collection - the closest I could come up with would be like The Postal Service or Owl City (for the use of electronic music), but that's a pretty weak comparison.  The single, \\"Pumped Up Kicks\\", was released earlier in an EP and will certainly be the track that draws a lot of people in.  It's an interesting track that juxtaposes a catchy hook with some pretty dark lyrics (\\"All the little kids with they're pumped up kicks, better run, better run, faster than my bullet\\").<br /><br />But the rest of the album really surprised me with how fun and danceable it is!  And again, this sort of electronic pop isn't really my thing, yet there probably aren't three other albums I'd rather listen to right now.  Some of the songs (\\"Don't Stop\\") rock out pretty hard, while others are much more laid back.  I don't feel like there's anything groundbreaking here, but that doesn't stop me from giving a 5-star review because this is one of the more addictive things I've heard in awhile.

B0013ND30M|5.0|My earliest memory is sitting on the couch watching this film in our living room on a Saturday afternoon. The moment I heard the ethereal vocals of Mary Costa as Briar Rose began her route into the forest, I became forever entranced by the magic of Disney animated storytelling. This film marks my first and most influential memory (I was not even 4). I was born (as my pen name indicates) right at the dawn of the Disney Renaissance which began with The Little Mermaid in 1989 and ended with Tarzan in 1999. So you would expect me to prefer something like The Lion King or Beauty and the Beast over something from three decades earlier, but behold, I was blessed with parents who failed to take me to see those films before introducing me to the classics they had begun purchasing on VHS as soon as I was born (Sleeping Beauty, Pinnochio, The Great Mouse Detective, The Rescuers Down Under, Robin Hood, The Sword and the Stone, ect). The first film I saw in theaters was Aladdin(1992), and that was an experience in and of itself, but what its ultimate effect ended up being was an acute disappointment that I never got to see my first love on the wall-spanning theater screen. How thrilling it would have been to see Prince Phillip battle Maleficent with the George-Bruns-adapted-Tchaikovsky score blasting through the speakers!    If you love classical music, if you are any kind of romantic, and most of all, if you value the innocence and grandeur of the Disney Classics, then you need to add this film to your library! Anyone who claims this film is boring was deprived of artistic appreciation in their life and lacks innocence, which is their very great misfortune. You could pause this film at any point, print out the image, frame it, hang it up on your wall, and visitors would almost swear you had a masterpiece in your home. What the story does (admittedly) lack in character development and plot depth is more than compensated for in the artistic design and scope alone. Let us not evenbegin to get into the brilliant score composed by the masterful and gifted Peter Tchaikovsky! This is a fairytale beloved by generations, and despite criticism on Disney's \\"romanticizing\\" of the classic folktales of Western culture, I dare anyone to name another film version of this story, if one exists that comes even close to creating the same effect on the audience in any aspect! I am inclined to believe that no such version (animated or live-action) can raise their hand because this film tops them all...it was and to this day, still is, the pinnacle of achievement in animation.    You do not have to get so involved with the \\"story\\" to be able to enjoy this film. Watching Sleeping Beauty is like going to the symphony or being able to value and appreciate art in any form. And for all the naysayers complaining, the morality and presentation of the characters is still communicated effectively. Aurora is innocent, yet exudes a grace and maturity that is unheard of in Disney heroines. Prince Phillip is the prototype prince for all the rest: daring, dignified, yet down-to-earth. The three good fairies are as warm, affectionate, and kind-hearted as any doting grandmother could be, and last, but certainly not least, Maleficent is the epitome of evil and cruelty. She doesn't have to have a reason to show up and cause havoc in King Stephan's realm...her performance at the christening party was just for show! She is evil because she loves evil and hates everything affiliated with good. With the notable exception of Chernabog from Fantasia(1940), you cannot find a more similar representation of Satan, himself. And any individual who plans to kidnap your betrothed and keep him away from you until he is old and decrepit is a prime definition of cruel and unusual punishment! Finally, the battle between Phillip and our archvillainess is the confirmation that, even with the advent of the computer, animators are STILL trying to top the look of this film. I rode home on a bus withmy basketball team one week from a tournament a few years ago and had brought a handful of movies to watch on the way...most of them iconic classics I might add (Gone With the Wind, Sound of Music ect.). They voted on Sleeping Beauty, and most of them hadn't seen the film for a good ten years. By the finale, even my coaches were thanking me for picking this movie! I could tell they were impressed!    If you have a spare couple of hours on the weekend, give this film a go, yes, even if you do not have a little girl who is less than 8 years old nearby. Sleeping Beauty's overlaying message that \\"love conquers all\\" is more adequately communicated through the audio and visual presentation than the most complex romantic comedy or raunchiest tv drama ever!
0316056863|5.0|Let me start by saying that I am a huge Tina Fey fan - I loved her on SNL and I watch 30 Rock religiously. So it's not a surprise that I'm a fan of her book. That said, it was hilarious at times, and touching at others. Well worth the read.
0062004352|3.0|I'm a little surprised how much I liked this one. A girl sleeping with TWO guys! At the same time....gasp! 0060853972|5.0|I listened to this book on a road trip - it was a lot of fun.  Irreverent and funny, you could hear the two authors' style and voices.  Some of the humor was very British, but that's the kind of humor I like, so it was well worth the time.
B004Y1USV2|4.0|It sounds cliche, but truly the one constant of YES is change:  Changes in timing, changes in mood...........and changes in personnel.  \\"Fly From Here\\" is the first effort with Benoit David in charge of vocals, and he does not disappoint - clear lead vocals and rich harmonies with Chris Squire abound.  I won't even ponder the validity of the vocals - these are Benoit's songs, not Jon Anderson's.  The foundation of Chris Squire's bass and Alan White's percussion is as solid as ever, punctuated by Steve Howe's and Geoff Downes' signature \\"Drama-tic\\" chops.  The 6-part title track (weighing in at almost 24 minutes) is bold if only because few are daring such epics these days - no radio support for this one!  The other tracks sound like a history lesson of other YES eras, with a bit of Pink Floyd, Alan Parsons Project and Nektar thrown in. I suggest giving it more than one listen to absorb the nuances that are present in all YES music before making final judgment.  All in all, I feel \\"Fly From Here\\" is a solid prog effort that will eventually stand very well on its own.  Finally, I ask the seemingly ever-present,elder/somewhat critical YES faithful (I've been a YesFan since 1972) to just relax and be grateful that this most recent incarnation of very talented musicians have graced us with yet another quality release.

B000000QFV|5.0|I love EVERYTHING Sabbath has done, from the first album to \\"Forbidden\\". If you're a 'true' fan of Black Sabbath, then you should know that EVERY album has a different sound and approach than the next, each one being extremely innovative and evolutionary in the rock world. Notice how many imitators that have been getting famous stealing Sabbath's sound ever since the 80's through til now.<br /><br />As for \\"Tyr\\", it had to grow on me when I first bought it when it came out, but then I immediately took to it, for after \\"Seventh Star\\", \\"The Eternal Idol\\", and \\"Headless Cross\\", \\"Tyr\\" sounded like a FULL band again, like they hadn't sounded like since \\"Mob Rules\\". I believe in time (especially since \\"Mob Rules\\" is some people's favorite of the Dio era, like myself) that people will come to like \\"Tyr\\" just as much.<br /><br />And, as for people referring to it as Iommi solo period, well, they couldn't be more wrong. Iommi was the only original member, but this was BLACK SABBATH through and through. Personally, I think Iommi could stand alone on stage, and still call it Black Sabbath.<br /><br />It's comparable to \\"Mob Rules\\" in that it was the only (and last) album from Sabbath after \\"Mob Rules\\"  that had such 'epic' songs. Well, \\"Born Again\\" & \\"Headless Cross\\" came close, but I thought that \\"Tyr\\" had stuff that sounded more like songs like \\"The Sign of the Southern Cross\\" and \\"Falling Off the Edge of the World\\". I especially love \\"The Sabbath Stones\\", \\"Anno Mundi\\", \\"Jerusalem\\", and \\"Valhalla\\". \\"Anno Mundi\\" and \\"The Sabbath Stones\\" are two of my favorites from \\"Tyr\\".<br /><br />And as for the line-up (Tony Martin - vocals, Tony Iommi - guitar, Neil Murray - bass, and Cozy Powell - drums), well, as I said, I think this was the strongest version of Black Sabbath since the 1981 line-up that recorded \\"Mob Rules\\" (and \\"Live Evil\\"). This was possibly the BEST Tony Martin era cd! Every song on this rocked.<br /><br />Tony Martin hits notes that are just earth shattering!  And as for Neil Murray, once they got him in the band, they should have forgotten about Geezer Butler. I still think Neil Murray was the perfect person to feel Butler's shoes. His work on \\"Tyr\\" (as well as the \\"Headless Cross\\" and the \\"Tyr\\" tours) was phenomenal. Sure beat the h*ll out of Dave \\"The Beast\\" Spitz, Bob Daisley, Jo Burt, and Laurence Cottle.<br /><br />I have read on certain threads that some Sabbath fans feel like the Iommi/Powell team-up didn't 'gel'. WRONG!! I thought that Cozy Powell was the best thing to ever happen to Black Sabbath, other than Vinnie Appice, my main inspiration as a drummer myself. But, everyone is entitled to their own opinion.<br /><br />And, this version of the band was awesome live! But, then again, they were all great live! That was the neat thing about Sabbath, they offered such great diverse talent.<br /><br />\\"The Kingdom of Odin is the Kingdom of God's, where only souls of the brave may rest in peace.\\"<br />\\"Lucifer's to blame, the reason for the Flame; they've taken your sight but they won't take your God!\\" - Black Sabbath, 1990.<br /><br />Highly recommended! Thank you! :>)s for Neil Murray, once they got him in the band, they should have forgotten about Geezer Butler. I still think Neil Murray was the perfect person to feel Butler's shoes. His work on \\"Tyr\\" (as well as the \\"Headless Cross\\" and the \\"Tyr\\" tours) was phenomenal. WRONG!! I thought that Cozy Powell was the best thing to ever happen to Black Sabbath, other than Vinnie Appice, my main inspiration as a drummer myself. That was the neat thing about Sabbath, they offered such great diverse talent.<br /><br />\\"The Kingdom of Odin is the Kingdom of God's, where only souls of the brave may rest in peace.\\"<br />\\"Lucifer's to blame, the reason for the Flame; they've taken your sight but they won't take your God!\\" - Black Sabbath, 1990.<br /><br />Highly recommended! B000005RQT|5.0|This album is just stunning. It really showcases the depth this group has had on instramentals. I feel ashamed for having had no idea about the origional intro for Speed King! I can't imagine that song without it now. The keyboard and extra effects in here definately add to the atmosphere and don't overpower the music. Living Wreck and Hard Lovin' Man show what good use of effects can create.<br />  I love Child In Time, and after reading the sleeve's story about them recording in the same house as Uriah Heep, it made perfect sence. If you match up Child in Time with UH's July Morning, they seem almost identical, to the fault of Heep! But still a good lesson in rock history.<br />  But honestly, my favorite part about this 25th Anniversary edition is the bonus material. That's one of the perks of living in a time well after this came out. Cry Free is such an amazing and unrelenting song I don't know why it wasn't included in the origional album! Jam Stew is another masterwork in instramental power! And I've grown very fond of the piano version of Speed King- not to the point of it replacing the origional, just like the different flavor. It's a rougher version and that works for me!<br />  Infact that is, in some ways how I would describe this whole album. Rough but well done. It's so organic and natural sounding reguardless of mixing. I love just hearing these guys wail.

B004Y1USV2|4.0|I'm only a peripheral Yes fan.  I grew up in their heyday, but I tended to be much more in the Genesis and King Crimson camp when it came to rabid fandom.  Of course I had \\"Fragile\\", \\"Close to the Edge\\" and the others and I played them regularly.  Oh, and I loved Jon Anderson's first solo album \\"Olias of Sunhillow\\" . . . . actually liked it a bit more than the band's stuff.  In the intervening years I didn't give the band a lot of attention . . . \\"Tormato\\" really soured me . . . . but I'd listen to their new releases when I could.  None of it made much of an impression, certainly not to the point of buying them.  But I have to say \\"Fly From Here\\" is a big improvement.  It's melodic, catchy, proggy and pop all at once.  I've given it a number of run-throughs and it keeps growing on me.  It's identifiably Yes without that desperate feel of trying to recapture past glory.    As for David vs Anderson, I thought it was Trevor Horn singing on first listen . . . the record comes closest to \\"Drama\\" in sound (not surprising considering the line-up, of course).    So my comments are aimed at the passer-by, not the hard core faithful.  If you liked them at one time but haven't found their more recent records to your taste you might want to give this a listen.

B004DI7HZ6|3.0|The premise of A Discovery of Witches is intriguing; a blend of witches, vampires, and daemons all vying to unlock the mystery of an enchanted book that may hold secrets that they all desire to learn.  However, somewhere along the way, the author became more interested in turning a fantasy adventure story into a romance novel between a vampire and a witch.  She vacillates between the heroine being portrayed as a strong, independent, powerful witch, and a swooning, helpless witch who is totally dependent upon her forbidden love, the vampire, to save her from the multitudes of monsters that are after her.   There were times that I just wanted to shout, \\"Make up your mind!\\" to the author.      As the story continued, the heroine discovers more and more powers within herself, each one a little more unbelievable than the last.  In my mind, this did not succeed in making her a well-rounded three dimensional character, it just made the plot a little lame.    I did enjoy the book, but felt that it got bogged down in the middle where it over-relied on romance to further the plot.      Although I might be curious enough to read the sequel if I borrowed it from the library, I will think twice before spending $14.99 for a download of one of her books.

B004KAB4I8|4.0|Well, this is one little book you'll really like if you wish to learn the basics of Dragon Drawing. It's full of details and lessons that will get you drawing a dragon with relative ease, and, if you practice enough, developing a knack for it.     I must say, however, this is mostly a practical \\"I show, you copy\\" kind of book, which is not wrong at all. The thing  is you can only get so far by merely reading it. The tools that the author provides are enough to draw your own dragons, yes, but you gotta try them at your own pace and in your own terms to truly master them. It takes a while, unless you already know your pencil-handling, but it's really satisfying to get it right.     Anyway, there's a lot to be learned from this book: different shapes become different kinds of dragons, anatomy for an imaginary creature, different details you can add to your magnificent Wyrm, and enough examples to show how these principles merge into amazing art. I definitely recommend this book to anyone who is taking the first steps into fantasy art.     And, if you combine it with other books by Peffer -the new one on dragons or the one about other fantasy creatures- you will surely get the most of them. Believe me, I have done it.

B0002Z0EYA|2.0|This was so absurd that I kept laughing. The film makers were obviously more concerned with mass battle scenes and special effects than the development of the characters and the minor matter of remaining true to 'The Iliad'doesn't come into it.<br /><br />The script is downright bad. Two choice quotes sum it up:- 'Immortality awaits you. Take it!' 'Of all the Warlords loved by the gods, I hate him the worst.'<br /><br />This being so, I couldn't blame the actors in having difficulty in imparting humanity to such cardboard characters:- There's the 'Invincible Warrior Who Needs a Good Woman to Get in Touch with His Emotions', the 'Meglomaniac King' the 'Nice Fiesty Girl' and the 'Caddish Young Prince Who Must Grow Up'. You get the general idea...<br /><br />I suppose that was why in general, the acting was wooden, though it varied. Helen is more impressive later on and always lovely to look at and Peter O'Toole as King Priam and Sean Bean as Odysseus are brilliant, while Hector, Andromache and the less-than-heroic Paris are good. I thought the part where Helen comforts Paris after his cowardice in the battle with Menelaus was sweet.<br /><br />I assume that Brad Pitt's sullen, impassive-faced Achilles was script and director driven. He's generally a good actor, and I know he read 'The Iliad' before acting in this.<br /><br />Briesis is supposed to be brave, independent minded and spiritual, but somehow comes across as insipid. There is something tediously inevitable about the love affair between her and Achilles; her 'spirited' defence,then her surrender. The poor girl goes on to develop a violent case of 'Stockholm Syndrome'. For anyone interested, I go into this in more detail in my review on the F Word but I don't think I am allowed to quote the link under the Amazon guidelines.<br /><br />I think it was because of the abusive-relationship-aspect that meant that the last scene between these lovers,which should be touching, left me dry-eyed.<br /><br />In fact, BradPitt's impassive face throughout was so unstimulating that I found my attention wandering from the action to questions such as:- Whether his tan was that spray-on stuff that body builders use to accentuate their muscles? Why his skin looked so oddly rubbery? Why he alone, of all the warriers, was smothered in oil - possibly filched from Hector and Andromache's delightful baby?<br /><br />Also, and quite unreasonably, I didn't find him a believable Achilles with that tiny nose of his - I couldn't believe in an Achilles without one of those lovely long Greek noses he is always depicted as having in ancient vase paintings, etc. That was unfair of me, as nobody else had such a nose, so why hold it against Brad PItt?<br /><br />This is good to have a laugh over with a group of friends, but if you want a serious modern take on The Iliad, look elsewhere...
