0439023513|3.0|Katniss makes lots of choices in Mockingjay that are NOT the choices of the independent girl who hunts & survives by her wits, hard work & talent. She has the will to live & the determination to survive mainly because she loves her mother and sister, & later also because she loves Gale & Peeta.     In the first two books, Katniss is FORCED to kill other people against her will. At the beginning of Mockingjay, she has her first real opportunity to finally make her own choices. There is no way that the Katniss we know from books one & two would have freely chosen to be used & paraded around ALL OVER AGAIN. Collins tries to give her the motivation of saving Peeta as her reason for agreeing to be the Mockingjay. But 13 had no control of Peeta's fate at that point. That's not nearly enough to trade for her dignity & sense of purpose.      Katniss chose to kill Coin based on what? Information from Snow, of all people. Boggs' death scene is when Katniss, the experienced hunter & Hunger Games winner, would have certainly realized she could not proceed without unbiased, accurate information (aka \\"the Truth\\") about 13, the rebellion & Coin. In fact, she would have found out all she could from Boggs & other sources when he hinted at Coin's true character before that.     And really, Katniss chooses to die, but fails to kill herself because Peeta & guards stopped her? The girl we know from the first & second books would have taken no chances. That pill would have already been IN HER MOUTH as she prepared to kill Coin.    There's also no way Katniss would have ever voted \\"yes\\" to holding another hunger games with the Capital's children.  She would have known that would mean she's just as evil as Snow (& Coin). If Katniss says \\"yes\\" just to make Coin believe she supports her leadership, Collins could easily have let us hear Katniss think it through, as the author does with so many other, much less important decisions.     Here are other things I just can't swallow.    -Katniss &Gale limited to two hours hunting? Fat chance.   -If Katniss disagrees with the tactic to bomb rescuers treating the wounded from a first bombing, why does she fail to strenuously object & continue to go along with supporting 13 & the rebellion?   -Katniss trains to be a soldier? To kill again when she hates killing people? I don't think so.  -She kills a woman in the Capital without a thought because the squad needed a place to re-group? No, that woman could easily have been someone just like Effie, Cinna & the members of her prep team.     Lots of facts & motivation are totally missing, while we're subjected to lots of passages about Katniss' thoughts about other, much more trivial things. Katniss herself is telling this story, & Collins could have done a much better job of weaving the psychological impact of war, PTSD, despair & suicidal tendencies into our heroine's thoughts.

The book was also a very easy and simple read, another must read book! Hats of to Robert. Cannot wait to read: \\"The richest man in Babylon by George S Clason\\", and \\"the millionaire next door\\"

Not much to say about this one honestly    8. \\"Let Me Take You Home Tonight\\"- This has always been my least favorite song on the album...It starts off nice but it just gets faster at the end and I just don't care for it    Verdict: Get it. Just go to your local record store and get it. After you get it, (Quote the Liner Notes): \\"LISTEN TO THE RECORD!\\"    It doesn't matter what you like. You'll find at least one of these songs to be good.    And I will also say that Tom Scholz did an AMAZING JOB on remastering this album!

Here you have access and guidance to all parts of the 2010 Rules applicable to money cases, as well as the full text of the relevant Rules and the associated Practice Directions.<br /><br />Within its more than 500 pages, this handy paperback volume packs in a lot.  Logically organised, the book is divided into thirty-six parts, (for example `appeals' and `costs).  Each part presents, first, the commentary, then the Rules and Practice Directions, so you can easily look up whatever you need to know.  There's also an extensive index at the back for further ease of reference.<br /><br />The book, however, is more than just a book; it functions as an ongoing up-to-date resource, linked as it is to its companion familyprocedure dot com website, which is included in the price you pay for the book.  As the software is regularly updated -- normally quarterly - and self-contained, it can be installed on your PC, which means you have ready access to the latest resources, (even when you may not be able to connect to the Internet.)<br /><br />The programme provides amendments and additions to the Rules and practice directions, together with the latest edition of the commentary, plus an impressive array of other benefits, including tools, calculators and report-printing features.<br /><br />Family law cases concerning money -- as most of them do -- can be fraught enterprises;  all the more reason why Financial Remedies, with its accompanying @eGlance facilities proves such a timesaver in the course of everyday practice. 0345529057|5.0|A four-book paperback set available cheap for those who don't want to wait in line at the library. This is a VERY LONG read and makes considerable demands on the reader. There are about 1000 named characters, of whom a few dozen are central. Each chapter presents the perspective of one of the central characters. Thus the reader may struggle to recall where we are in a particular character's story when a new chapter recommences it.    Central characters range from pre-teens to matrons, and Martin handles female characters just as well as he does the males. There is an interesting range of temperaments and situations, although most of life as he sees it is pretty grim. One of his most interesting devices is to present a character peripherally, giving us a misleading idea of who that character is. Later we get the character's own perspective, which may considerably alter our perception. He also brings immiscible characters together and makes them learn how to get along. It is easy to become emotionally involved with several of Martin's protagonists.    The writing is colorful and gives a strong sense of place and time. Some of the set-pieces are epic, and he deploys an assortment of arresting devices, such as beginning a chapter with a sentence like, \\"The man on the roof was the first to die.\\" Another interesting dramatic device is to allow characters to remain ignorant of important events the reader knows of, realistically invoking the medieval barriers of time and distance, not to mention \\"fog of war\\".    In the \\"Sword and Sorcery\\" genre, this series leans to the former. As \\"Science Fiction\\" it favors the latter. It should not be lightly taken up, as it will be difficult to put down.

This is coming from a true fan who owns all of their stuff and knows it all well. 1451629184|5.0|I would be concerned about anyone who could read this book without difficulty. I had to pause frequently and just breathe to compose myself, and still feel sick to my stomach when I think of what she endured. It is a horrific story and yet beautifully written. Jaycee Lee Dugard is an extraordinary young woman and courageous in the extreme, not only because she survived her ordeal with compassion for herself as a victim and hope for the future, but because she tells her story in unflinching detail and with an unusual degree of introspection and analysis. It is astounding to learn that she does not hate her tormentors, that she does not want that type of negativity in her life (echoing the sentiments of many notable survivors of torture, extermination camps, extreme abuse, etc.) Amazing. What was done to her absolutely defies imagination - not only the sexual abuse and physical neglect but the extreme isolation, manipulation, and mind games. And she helps us clearly understand why she was unable to escape even after she was granted a degree of freedom. She is a hero and we all have something to learn from her story.

B004Y1USV2|5.0|A musical EXTRAVAGANZA from YES!<br /><br />YES has come up with another gem. This record sounds current and fresh considering its retro 80's roots. The mix of talent here goes back to the 'Drama' Album, circa 1980 incarnation of Yes, with Power Pop producer Trevor Horn at the helm as producer/backing Vocals, Geoff Downes (Buggles and Asia)-keyboards, founder Chris Squire-Bass, Steve Howe-Guitars, Alan White-Drums and Benoit David on Lead vocals. I didn't discover 'Drama' with Trevor Horn on Lead vocals until YES  performed 2 songs from 'Drama'at a Concert in Boca Raton, FL in February of 2010. After hearing 'Machine Messiah' and 'Tempus Fugit' I had to go out and buy the CD. It was kind of like having a new YES album 30 years after it was made. So, I think of 'Fly From Here'as being a sequel to 'Drama'. The music of YES is timeless. Trevor Horn has produced some good YES albums in the 80's such as '90125','Big Generator' and 'Drama' of course. The whole 'Fly From Here' album has a real nice feel and flows smoothly. I am very thankful Yes has graced us with such fine new music. 'Fly From Here' will grow on you as it is growing on me. 'Into the Storm'is my favorite track so far. YES, was what it was and today it is what it is.  A band that continues to evolve which is much better than having no YES at all.<br /><br />After many listens, I love the whole Album, I believe 'Fly From Here' is the total package and is a Masterpiece for the 21st century. 'Fly From Here' now ranks second to my all time favorite 'The YES Album'. So, move yourself and get a copy today...you will be glad you did.
B004Y1USV2|4.0|This grumpy old man is a 38-year veteran fan of Yes, in other words, difficult to please. I had my doubts when I first heard the sound clips and would have given it only 2-3 stars, which is not fair. Well, after running all over creation this morning on the day of it's release, I finally found a copy that I did not have to order, because getting a copy before the concert only three days away was my goal.<br /><br />I won't bore you with the details. It is way better than the average drek being released these days by other groups, and way better than Open Your Eyes or 90125. Will it stand the test of time and become a five-star classic like Close To The Edge or Relayer? Too soon to tell. Is it progressive? In it's own way, yes. Is it pop? Got that covered without being overtly commercial. Is Steve Howe's guitar and all of the vocal harmonies prominent? You bet. Enough for now. Just get it!<br /><br />Update: I finally got to watch the DVD, which is an interesting look at Trevor and the band in the studio discussing the making of this CD over a two-month period. Basically, they just trusted Trevor and it worked out great. Then I went looking for the live footage and could not find any. My copy does not specifically state this, so buyer beware. Since I had to have this in a hurry, I wound up spending an extra 8 bucks at my local retailer for something I will probably only watch once. For only 2 bucks more on Amazon, that's more like it and worth the chance. The lyric booklet is also included here, which I am not sure it is provided with the basic CD only. B003YL4LYI|5.0|\\"A Dance with Dragons\\" is the 5th book in the \\"A Song of Ice and Fire\\" series by George R. R. Martin. The hardcover is 1040 pages in length while the Kindle e-edition is a 2119 Kb download.<br /><br />SPOILERS<br /><br />Within the first few chapters you'll be reacquainted with Jon Snow, Tyrion, Daenerys and Bran. Four important players that were absent or scarcely mentioned in \\"A Feast of Crows\\".<br /><br />The location of these four individuals is as follows...<br /><br />1.) Jon Snow's story is at The Wall...probably my favorite tale.<br />2.) Tyrion's...travels through the Free Cities area...slow to get going but improved with time.<br />3.) Daenerys...at Meereen on the Slaver's Bay...a very slow tale to develop (to the point of thinking about skimming some of it).<br />4.) Bran...an interesting trek north of The Wall, with a less prominent role than the other three...one gets the feeling that there are important things in store for Bran in subsequent books.<br /><br />There were also several other individuals whose tales were very interesting, in particular Davos, (acting as the 'hand' for King Stannis Baratheon at the Isles of The Three Sisters and at White Harbour) and Theon (Lord Ramsey's prisoner).<br /><br />END SPOILERS<br /><br />In addition to this fine story, some other things I liked about the physical book itself...<br /><br />1.) three maps: Beyond the Wall, The Free Cities and Valyria. These maps seem to have greater detail, giving information on names, places, distances and direction. [but see Cons: 1.a) below]<br /><br />2.) an appendix in the back with an extensive Dramatis Personae...listing all the Houses (as well as lesser groupings), the characters within, their relationship to each other and sometimes, their present location.<br /><br />Concerns:<br />Regarding the maps...<br />1a.) in the Kindle format the maps are almost illegible. And unfortunately they become more indistinct as you expand them. This of course in not a flaw of the book but rather the limitation imposed by the Kindle rendering process.<br /><br />1b.) the three maps are hard to relate to each other. You have a vague sense of the geographic layout, but because there is no overall master map of the entire area, it is somewhat difficult to get a feel for the 'lay of the land' as to how the three maps provided are positioned geographically in relation to one another.<br /><br />2.) Daenerys tale...slow to develop and repetitive to the point of being annoying.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />With the return of the major characters of the previous books, my interest in this wonderful series has been rekindled.<br /><br />A definite improvement over \\"A Feast of Crows\\", not only because the more important characters have reappeared, but the intrigue and tension so familiar with the first three books (with the exception of Daenerys story), has returned as well.<br /><br />Overall, despite the minor concerns mentioned above, I loved it...after a hiatus of many years it's been worth the wait. And not unexpectedly, Book 5 ends with many situations and developments hanging in the balance.  4 1/2 Stars.<br /><br />Ray Nicholsonut rather the limitation imposed by the Kindle rendering process.<br /><br />1b.) the three maps are hard to relate to each other. B004WKOCP8|4.0|Well, this is somewhat of a pleasant surprise. In all honesty, I knew better then to expect the old school Incubus sound which so many fans have been missing, but this album is pretty interesting regardless. That being said this album is very, very different then what people are typically used to hearing from the band, but for me, I don't really care what direction a band goes in, just as long as the quality remains and this album feels genuine and inspired.       I honestly really like it. Its a more somber and subdued sound, much more laid back. Not quite as aggressive, but still very passionate and melodic. The songs all blend together well and there is a consistent sound from beginning to end, and very pleasingly, there doesn't seem to be any filler.       In the end, this is a pretty decent album which I think may end up dividing fans. Some people might be going in expecting SCIENCE or Make Yourself and they may be disappointed, but for me personally I really haven't enjoyed an Incubus album this much since Morning View so its nice to have such a solid album. So if you are open to something different, its definitely worth checking out.
B005869U6G|4.0|I can see how many people may be disappointed with this album. It definitely sounds different than any of their previous work and people who still cling to the Incubus from Morning View, Make Yourself, and previous albums will probably not be that happy with this. The thing is that you have to understand that band progress and evolve just like the individual members. Dirk hasn't been their bassist since Morning View and although Kenney is a talented musician, his sound and style is different. You shouldnt expect the sound to have remained the same which is definitely evident in their previous 2 albums and now this one.     This album is very mellow compared to previous albums. I remember my teenage years and listening to S.C.I.E.N.C.E. connecting with intensity of the instrumental and combined vocals. But now I find myself at a different stage of my life and listening to this album still allows me to connect to the music in a way I wouldn't be able to if it still had the same intensity as previous albums.     In all honesty, I was not a huge fan of this album when I first listened to it a month or so ago, but nevertheless it ended up on my iPod. After several long NYC subway commutes it really grew on me, especially the melodic tranquility. Not every song is a winner but they are all unique just like the band that made them. You just have to keep in mind that just like people, bands can change and move in different directions too. Although I would have enjoyed this album much more a year ago, I still enjoy Incubus.
B004ZZS4CC|5.0|Very interesting true story about a young girl age eleven, who is abducted, raped repeatedly, and forced to live in her abductors' shed in their back yard. It shows how over time a young person can learn to adapt to new surroundings and feel \\"at home\\" with their captors. There are numerous cases of young children who after years of brainwashing do not run away from their captors when given an opportunity. This book helps us to understand why.....  And hopefully educates us to not ask stupid questions like \\"why didn't you save yourself?\\"  After a decade one is more afraid of the outside world and what they have been told about it than they are of the life that they have come to be accustomed to. Jaycee is one strong woman and definitely a role model for all of us. No matter what problems we are facing, we can get through them if this young girl could survive the trauma and pure hell that she went through. She gave birth to that monster's child at age thirteen with no medical attention!!!!  Amazing. And what is even more amazing is that her abductor had 64 visits by parole officers because of his history as a sex offender and NONE of them checked the back yard. B004Y1USV2|4.0|OK, just listened to 'Fly From Here' for the first time, so here are the first impressions. This album sounds like what the followup to 'Drama' should have sounded like. Overall, it's a good album and is very listenable. It is much more like 'Drama' or even a Buggles album, and this is not necessarily a bad thing. Alan White and Chris Squire give the music a solid foundation as always, but Squire is kind of subdued on this album. Geoff Downes' keyboards are very good, if a bit reminiscent of the 1980's. Benit David is not Jon Anderson, get over it (and I say this as a huge Anderson fan). David's performance is also very good, actually sounding more like Trevor Horn than Jon Anderson. Finally, Steve Howe. Mr. Howe takes names and kicks butt on this album. His guitar work shines on this album!    Bottom line: This is going to be another divisive Yes album, like 'Drama' and 'Tales'. People will either love it or hate it. If you are a fan of 'Drama', you will probably like this album.

B004ZZS4CC|5.0|Wow.  I just read Jaycee's account of her captive life from cover to cover.  Or should I say, JAYCEE.      I watched an interview with her the night before the release of her book, and was captivated by this beautiful, calm, and unexpectedly wise woman.  I knew I wanted to read her story, even though I must admit the interview alone woke me up with nightmares.  I just needed to know how someone so genuine and humane could emerge from such an experience.    Jaycee does a beautiful job of telling her unbelievable story without self-pity, which it makes it all the more heart-wrenching.  It's hard to read the more gruesome aspects of the book; her pedophile captor is as sick as you would imagine.  I will forever be haunted by the image of a 11 year old girl locked naked in a shed in California during the summer, handcuffed for weeks (or months?), left to the stifling heat without food and water unless her predator brings it to her.  Towels covering the window; alone in the dark with nothing but ants and spiders and an occasional appearance by the child predator, who I don't even want to name (after all, he wouldn't use Jaycee's name so I won't repeat his.)     As the story and Jaycee's existence evolves, Jaycee's true spirit and humanity emerges.  Her connection and love for animals is striking yet sad, as they provided her with the companionship and love so lacking in her world.  Her desire to be \\"liked\\" and accepted by her female captor (also unworthy of a name) was fascinating and yet understandable.  In a way, reading the book, you fall victim to the same emotions... wanting She-who-shall-not-be-named to accept and love Jaycee.  It was very interesting to hear Jaycee describe her struggle with the baby weight, trying to make better food choices and \\"exercise\\" even inside of captivity.  I guess societal pressures are truly pervasive if they could penetrate concealed backyards and soundproof sheds.    Jaycee's pregnancy, and then her second pregnancy seem so awful andunjust from the outside.  However, her beautiful daughters would never have been in existence if it weren't for her terrible tragedy, and I think that they provided Jaycee with a reason for her experiences; an explanation and worthy cause for the evil in her life.     It's hard to understand how Jaycee didn't run; didn't take her daughters and flee, didn't scream at the parole officers or climb the fence to the neighbors.  However, I think the reader has to remember Jaycee was taken at the tender age of 11, before she had any real experience of control over her world.  She did not have the opportunity to make any real choices in her life. And the real invisible shackles were her two daughters; Jaycee didn't know how they would survive on the outside.    So would I recommend this book?  Absolutely.  And I hope Jaycee sells a hundred million copies and can live the rest of her life by the sea with all the pets she can possibly tolerate.  And I hope her captors rot in hell.

B004QM8HV2|4.0|This is a delightful recording of one of Massenet's biggest hits. It owes its quality to the exceptional tenderness of Frederica Von Stade's portrayal of Cendrillon and the slickness of ensemble; it has the right combination of pathos and sparkling insouciance needed to bring off this operatic pantomime. At the helm, the experienced Julius Rudel treats the score with affection and respect, securing lovely playing from the Philharmonia; there is pace and drive when needed but he relaxes into Cendrillon's sad, solo arias to elicit maximum sweetness from the music.<br /><br />Von Stade is vocally in finest estate: her pianissimi are exquisite, top notes are floated - she even touches on a high D - and she brings her special gift of plangency to bear upon a role made for her voice. The bug in the butter is Gedda's Prince Charming; he's not exactly a disaster but already by this stage of his career, when he was 53, his tenor is bleaty and unsteady and has lost tonal centre in the middle of the voice; one can only imagine what a younger-voiced singer might have done to make the prince more seductive. Still their duet at the ball with its haunting refrain and at the ecstatic conclusion of Act 3 go very nicely and some may tolerate him better than do I; I have never been much of a fan of his sound. Ruth Welting, Von Stade's regular recital partner, is absolutely enchanting as the Fairy Godmother, despatching her exacting coloratura with ease. The fairy scenes are charming, with the chorus set well back to create a suitably ethereal ambience.<br /><br />It is a pity that when Sony issues classic performances such as this in bargain sets the inevitable casualty is libretto, as with so much quickfire exchange in French between the henpecked Pandolfe and his gruesome family you really need to be able to follow the dialogue, especially as we have old hands like Jules Bastin and Jane Berbi&eacute; making the most of his reaction to the invective launched at him. The touch of acid in her voice and the invariably plaintive note in his accentuate the comedy, rendering him more sympathetic and her even more hateful than usual, so that we welcome the moment when the worm turns and he turns them out shrieking.<br /><br />So, the slight reservation concerning Gedda's contribution notwithstanding, this is an entirely successful recording unlikely to be surpassed.<br /><br />PS: following the pertinent comment by a fellow reviewer below, I am happy to add that the original Prince was a soprano-Falcon in a breeches role. It is especially regrettable that it is not thus performed in this recording as Gedda is its weakness.r voice and the invariably plaintive note in his accentuate the comedy, rendering him more sympathetic and her even more hateful than usual, so that we welcome the moment when the worm turns and he turns them out shrieking.<br /><br />So, the slight reservation concerning Gedda's contribution notwithstanding, this is an entirely successful recording unlikely to be surpassed.<br /><br />PS: following the pertinent comment by a fellow reviewer below, I am happy to add that the original Prince was a soprano-Falcon in a breeches role. It is especially regrettable that it is not thus performed in this recording as Gedda is its weakness.

B004NSULHM|5.0|This album, like all albums that have been born from the collective radiohead mind, asks that you either commit to a serious listen or a passing scoff. If you are truly willing to take the ride that is this album you will find for yourself, as I have, that this is certainly a worthy record and possibly one of their best to date-which is saying something considering this band is one of the greatest of our era. Critics seem to have listened to this album once or twice and then tried to pass their \\"well trained\\" judgement in time for their opinion to be posted first, when in fact this album demands you spend the time to look behind every wall and feel out all the dark textured corners. This album cannot be seen or felt if you arent interested in spending the time to find it. Those who throw it on and expect some immediate beat to hit, and shallow lust to rush over you then you have picked the wrong artist and should stick with what pleases you. However, if you are still interested in the \\"album\\" as medium for art, and if you are willing to give it an honest chance to speak, then you will find it has a subtle hidden allure that most artists, and many fans find hard to grasp in todays \\"dowloaded single\\" world.     Yes, this is a low key radiohead which has receded back to a more minimal and less accessible sound. It is a stunning contrast to the dazzling outburst that was \\"In Rainbows\\". It shifts and it turns. It moves in ways you may not expect. However to say this album is predictable is to admit that you just havent been listening, or you just dont understand. This takes from newer acts such as dub step favorites burial, and older friends like four tet, creating a unmistakably unique core while allowing rythmic off center beats to circle around and pulse while haunting, sprawling melodies swirl and yawn. Yorke's voice and lyrics are cryptic and allusive for most of the record, while comforting and clearing when need be. This album draws you in without you realizing itand while slowly passing by, almost unnoticed, it combines almost flawlessly the best of minimialist electronic in one hand and the honesty and and complexity of strong song writing and experienced technical ability in the other. Radiohead continues their tradition of creating music which lies on the border between underground wankery, pop mainstream, and honest to god hard work and talent. While this album can at times be very detatched and almost unfriendly in its approach, it does so with the intent of keeping its distance just enough to keep you guessing and coming back for more.     I have no doubt that this album, like many albums from this outfit, will crawl into the souls of its listeners and months or years from now you will hear from people what an amazing and soothing album this truly is. The best friend who is willing to tell you the hard truth, even when it hurts. This album will eventually be realized and looked back on as underrated in its day. Built with so much care. Drawn together with so many layers. And passed over because it just didnt strike the right chord the first time. Perhaps all the critics that let this album slip by as a lesser outing were just too busy talking to really listen. Perhaps they were just waiting for that special something they invisioned would happen, instead of really letting this beauty unfold and as it was written and given. Not as the bombshell your waiting to walk in the door and blow you away---but as the quiet friend that is always by your side that you have always overlooked, until suddenly you see.    All I can ask of those of you who would honestly want an experience with this album is to forget what you know about radiohead, and forget what you expect from them as an artist. Lay down in a quiet, dark room at night--or drive the streets slowly after everyone has gone to bed, and let this album wash over you again and again on its own terms. For me it stands out, not as the complex, intensive answer that took hours to solve, but the simple truth that you could never see until you pulled back and realized the whole picture.
0307455378|5.0|This riveting story of a writer explores the world of fantasy, dreams and illusions. Carlos Ruiz Zafn's, El Juego de ngel is a powerful story.
B004WKOCP8|4.0|For all the fans that are lashing out at the lack of heavy music here, I can understand your concern. The heavier element of this band is a part of Incubus which is amazing and a part I agree they have not explored to my satisfaction. It is frustrating to see a band with so much obvious talent and vision move away from what you loved so much about them and what you could see them doing. I love a good guitar thrashing from mike just like anyone else and I can always use an upbeat incubus rocker which shows how useless most mainstream junk really is.     That said, I cannot honestly listen to this album and write it off because it is not what I wanted or expected. If this band were to produce only what everyone wanted, there would be no expression or art to the work. You cant very well ask an artist to create something they dont feel like making. Listening to this album reminds me that Incubus is one artist who is still willing to follow their interests and give us something honest and real. This album expores a whole different side of Incubus, one we have seen on occassion on the last few albums. This softer more personalized album gives us a taste of what Mike can do outside of the large chord world. It shows Brandon's voice and message very clearly, while maintaining a musicial interest with strong core structure to each song. This album is filled with melody and purpose and is built as a whole piece. I think it is unfair, to say the least, to judge this without the perspective of time. All Incubus albums need time to grow and build and there really is so many layers of material here that it will take time to really dig in and see what this album has to offer. Its lush soundscapes and open unashamed honesty may come across as simple and lazy but really I feel like you have to take it as it is and not as you would have it be. It stands on mature song writing and builds its appeal not by being showy or heavy, but instead by pulling melodies together into interwoven staggering tunes which emphasis the use of space and minimalism. Each member still contributes significantly to this release but not by push their skill but instead by pushing their emotional boundaries. Giving up a solo to keep the focus on the melody. Drumming tightly but calmly to maintain and accent the song. This album reminds me of classical music structure in that their are such large chord transitions without being obvious and flahy. The ideas presented in the lyrics are still thoughtful and ask the listener to think and consider their meaning. Ultimately this album reminds me that sometimes less really can be more.     Like most Incubus fans I am waiting for album on which Incubus decides to let loose and show the world what they can truely do as musicians. I long for the energy and experiment of SCIENCE or the smashing anger of Make Yourself. But until these guys decide to channel that demon, I am enjoying their turn at showing their softer side and penning some very interesting and well written ballads and melodies.

159420229X|5.0|We got this book for the Kindle and sent it to several of our family's kindles. Our two oldest kids (14 and 13) devoured it and I really enjoyed it as well.<br /><br />On Saturday evening, my wife and I and five kids sat around the living room and took turns making a list of words to memorize -- 21 words in all. We then made mental a trip from our driveway though our house, placing the words at various points with vivid images that we enjoyed creating together.<br /><br />About an hour from when we started, all of us could say the list perfectly in order, including our 6-year-old, and the older ones then said it backwards as well with no problems. I'm sure we could have done 30 or 40 words, maybe more. The next day all still remembered the list.<br /><br />It was a fun family time, and this is a fun book. We've since ordered a couple more books on the same topic and are eagerly awaiting their arrival.
B004Y1USJE|5.0|When I heard Yes was coming out with a new album I was excited and couldn't wait to get it. They are, in my opinion, one of the most influential rock bands of all time. But then I heard Jon Anderson, their vocalist for much of their career, would not be singing, and I was disappointed... Almost reluctant to listen. Though I was very skeptical at first, I'm so glad that I gave it shot. The band, consisting of Benoit David on vocals, along with Chris Squire (bass), Steve Howe (guitar), Alan White (drums) and Geoff Downes (keyboards) sounds amazing. The production is crisp and fresh, and, most importantly, the songs are awesome. \\"Fly From Here\\" gets things going and is a 5 part, more then 20 minute long song that includes \\"Overture\\" as well as \\"Fly From Here\\" parts I - V. This isn't really something Yes has done before: It has a darker, more atmospheric feel then typical Yes songs. The main chorus is phenomenal, and Steve Howe's playing will blow your mind! He shows his true nature as a virtuoso as he alternates between an astral slide guitar, a straight ahead attack, and the perfect blend of melody, Spanish-influenced guitars, and scorching solos. As is typical of his style, his playing enhances each and every song, adding dramatic textures and harmonies that only he is capable of. The result is a fresh sounding masterpiece that even long time, diehard fans of the band will love.  \\"The Man You Always Wanted Me To Be\\" is a Squire-penned ballad with more amazing guitars and bass. And while he'll never be Jon Anderson, Benoit David's vocals are spot on and he can really deliver! \\"Life on a Film Set\\" starts off slow and mellow but gains energy and intensity; I was sucked in and couldn't help playing it over and over to catch every nuance. \\"Into the Storm\\" closes out the CD with a bang. It has some cool analog synth guitars in which Howe shows off his wide repertoire of licks and features some of the best multi layered vocal harmonies I've heard in a long time. From startto finish this is an incredible album that leaves you wanting more. I would highly recommend it to anyone!
0061784788|4.0|At the outset of this review, I need to make a couple of things clear:<br /><br />1. I was asked by the PR dept. at Harper Collins if I would accept a free copy of this book and review it. I imagine they asked me (along with other Mormon writers/bloggers) to do this due to the book's subject matter including Mormons and Mormon history. I accepted, without any strings attached.<br /><br />2. There exists no agreement that I would necessarily review this book favorably. The review below is my honest appraisal of this book with zero input from Harper Collins.<br /><br />3. I believe that I am the target audience for this book. I am an adult male who loves espionage, thrillers, and history.<br /><br />4. I'm assuming that since I am obviously Mormon and Harper Collins asked me to do this review that they wanted me to add a Mormon perspective. What I say in this review is NOT an official position of my church, but it IS my very nit-picky take on how Mr. Rollins treats his subject matter.<br /><br />I shall start with my nit picking so that I can get it out of the way and review the book on its overall merit.<br /><br />Nits and Picks:<br /><br />1. Maggie Grantham is a BYU professor (not explicitly described as LDS). Hank Kanosh is a Mormon and BYU professor as well. He chews stogies, which is referred to in the book as a necessary concession, but there is a reference to a tryst between these two, with no judgement of such a thing. LDS doctrine considers an extra-marital sexual tryst as far more serious than chewing on a stogie. This would be of extreme significance to these two people in the context of their LDS culture. It would inform much of these people's lives and what they do. Also, both professors are expected to live by BYU's honor code; a sexual tryst is far, far outside that code.<br /><br />2. Referring to the Mormon church as the Church of Latter-Day Saints is a sign of an incomplete knowledge of the church, its doctrine and history. It's officially called the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, shortened to the LDS church, the Mormon church, or the Mormons.<br /><br />3. Joseph Smith is the name of the man who translated the golden plates, which translation became the Book of Mormon. Rollins gets this right early in the book, but inexplicably starts calling him John Smith about halfway through the book and never gets it right again.<br /><br />4. There is a point in the book wherein Kanosh (remember, a Mormon from birth) ostensibly seems to be meeting the prophet/president of the LDS church to give him something of great value. Kanosh does this in the Salt Lake City temple, apparently right outside the Holy of Holies. Not likely at all. And Kanosh kneels in front of the prophet. That's very not Mormon. People meet the LDS prophet all the time. We shake his hand and absolutely do NOT worship the man.<br /><br />And that, my friends, is it. Harmless little things. There are plenty of other interesting references to Mormon beliefs, particularly regarding the history of the peoples talked about in the Book of Mormon. But those are generally authorial fabrications made in order to tell the story.<br /><br />Now the review:<br /><br />James Rollins is very like a combination of Dan Brown, Matt Reilly, and Clive Cussler. I would say that he is all three of those authors on their best day. I liked The Devil Colony about 17,452 times more than anything I have read by Dan Brown, particularly since Rollins demonstrates zero addiction to melodramatic adverbs and this book was populated by real people who do things that exact a real price upon them.<br /><br />That's also why The Devil Colony is more effective than Clive Cussler's work, which I quite enjoy. Dirk Pitt, Cussler's usual hero, seems completely invincible and to always have the answers; there is never much doubt about the inevitable outcome of Pitt's adventures.<br /><br />Matt Reilly is another favorite thriller writer for me, and Rollins really compares wellto Reilly. The difference is that Reilly's action is so non-stop that you forget who's doing what sometimes. And there are a couple of eye rolls that come about with Reilly's work.<br /><br />I have to say I think The Devil Colony is the best modern thriller I have read in ages. This is because the characters really seem human. Kai is a particularly good character-- her inner dialogue is deftly done and she never seems like a throwaway character. But each person is flawed, and they each have relationships that motivate what they're doing.  They also all go through hell and pay a price for their narrow escapes and successes. I like it when a character uses ingenuity to fix the 'fix' that they're in.<br /><br />Another place that The Devil Colony shines is that it's a team effort. The Sigma Force is a group of folks who are all insanely intelligent and they work together. I like that they made solid use of modern technology to stay in touch and coordinate their efforts. The real-time sense of the pacing also lent a nice feeling of authenticity to the story. The characters are interesting and well developed, with plenty going on internally to lend tension to the conflicts around the characters.<br /><br />Rollins, like many other thriller writers, uses 3rd person omniscient, thus enabling him to allow the reader to follow the antagonist. This is effectively done in The Devil Colony, and again, it's far better than anything by Dan Brown. Browns' villains all feel like they're out of an old melodrama like Klondike Kalamity. Rafael Saint Germaine, the main antagonist of The Devil Colony, is an intriguing fellow whose secrets are murky but who seems like a real fellow. A bad fellow, mostly, but a real one.<br /><br />This is a big book. It comes in at 474 pages. But it was engaging enough and well paced to the point that I felt like it was a quick read. Even the prose is smooth and well-crafted. Rollins is clearly a master of this game.<br /><br />As a book-- a novel-length story-- I really don't have anything critical to say about The Devil Colony. It's very creative, manages cliffhangers very well, moves things along at a suitably breathless clip, makes you mostly care about the characters, and pulls some slick twists.<br /><br />I liked the book. As a dyed-in-the-wool, true-blue Mormon (a convert, yes, but nonetheless), I found nothing at which to take offense. Rollins takes a few liberties, but they're more or less innocuous. I'd like to chat with the fellow about some of his research, actually.<br /><br />I'd say, read the book. If you like thrillers, you'll love The Devil Colony. Vast in scope, daring in its implications, and rollicking in its action; it's a great read.<br /><br />4.5 out of 5 pens.re are a couple of eye rolls that come about with Reilly's work.    I have to say I think The Devil Colony is the best modern thriller I have read in ages. This is because the characters really seem human. Kai is a particularly good character-- her inner dialogue is deftly done and she never seems like a throwaway character. But each person is flawed, and they each have relationships that motivate what they're doing.  They also all go through hell and pay a price for their narrow escapes and successes. I like it when a character uses ingenuity to fix the 'fix' that they're in.    Another place that The Devil Colony shines is that it's a team effort. The Sigma Force is a group of folks who are all insanely intelligent and they work together. I like that they made solid use of modern technology to stay in touch and coordinate their efforts. The real-time sense of the pacing also lent a nice feeling of authenticity to the story. The characters are interesting and well developed, with plenty going on internally to lend tension to the conflicts around the characters.     Rollins, like many other thriller writers, uses 3rd person omniscient, thus enabling him to allow the reader to follow the antagonist. This is effectively done in The Devil Colony, and again, it's far better than anything by Dan Brown. Browns' villains all feel like they're out of an old melodrama like Klondike Kalamity. Rafael Saint Germaine, the main antagonist of The Devil Colony, is an intriguing fellow whose secrets are murky but who seems like a real fellow. A bad fellow, mostly, but a real one.     This is a big book. It comes in at 474 pages. But it was engaging enough and well paced to the point that I felt like it was a quick read. Even the prose is smooth and well-crafted. Rollins is clearly a master of this game.    As a book-- a novel-length story-- I really don't have anything critical to say about The Devil Colony. It's very creative, manages cliffhangers very well, moves things along at asuitably breathless clip, makes you mostly care about the characters, and pulls some slick twists.     I liked the book. As a dyed-in-the-wool, true-blue Mormon (a convert, yes, but nonetheless), I found nothing at which to take offense. Rollins takes a few liberties, but they're more or less innocuous. I'd like to chat with the fellow about some of his research, actually.    I'd say, read the book. If you like thrillers, you'll love The Devil Colony. Vast in scope, daring in its implications, and rollicking in its action; it's a great read.    4.5 out of 5 pens.

1451629184|5.0|This is an amazing memoir written by Jaycee Lee Dugard. It flows with great logic. It held my interest to the very last word. This despite the fact that she only attended school through the last days of fifth grade. There is proof that she had developed strong writing skills at an early age, for the book includes several strong handwritten pages from a journal about her beloved cat, Eclipse, composed when Jaycee was only thirteen. In the following years she managed to read enough (she cites T.S. Eliot and Dean Koontz) to maintain her ability to express herself in a highly articulate manner.    If only the entire story could be summed up by the above paragraph! But Jaycee was abducted at the age of eleven by a monster, Phillip Garrido, and his assistant, Nancy Garrido. Garrido repeatedly raped her. He threatened her. He manipulated her. He spewed out of his mouth his weird fantasies and schemes and forced Jaycee to listen. The physical and verbal abuse is described in graphic detail in this book.    Jaycee states that one objective she had when writing this was to inform people of the dangers posed by monsters like Garrido. She wants people to be more careful. Be more observant. Do not hesitate to contact the authorities if something appears to be strange.  You cannot read this book and not become more wary of sick people like the Garridos.    Jaycee describes the ramshackle shelters in which she was confined in Garrido's backyard. Basically, she was treated like an animal who was occasionally thrown scraps of kindness. She gave birth to two of Garrido's children. She cared for them as best she could while they were forced to endure squalor. She did a remarkable job as a mother. Her children are fortunate to have such an iron-tough mother.    Jaycee expresses in the book concern about why she did not try to escape, particularly after the first few years when she was not as closely confined as in the beginning. Her reluctance to attempt escape is explained by the terror inflicted upon her, the fear of what might happen to her children, the fear of the unknown world outside, and the fact that her thoughts were largely the product of Garrido's vicious manipulation.    I found this to be an outstanding primary source about how cruel people can be, and therefore a warning to all of us. And the fact that she was able to write this book after suffering eighteen years under the thumb of such a vile person is evidence of the resilience of the human spirit.    The book rings with the strength of the truth.
B004WKOCP8|4.0|\\"If Not Now, When?\\" is the sixth studio album that Incubus has released, and it is clearly one of their best. That said, if you go into this expecting another \\"S.C.I.E.N.C.E.,\\" you will be disappointed. However, if you go into this looking to experience the natural evolution of a band with catchy songs, great lyrics, and killer melodies, you will love it. The band sounds amazing, and Brandon Boyd's voice is better then ever. He has an incredible range, and he is able to combine raw power and melody like few others. Things get started with the title track, \\"If Not Now, When?\\" and the sound is phenomenal. This is a heavily instrumental track, and Boyd's vocals provide a perfect texture over the straight ahead attack of the guitars. While the heavy guitars are noticeably absent on \\"Promises, Promises,\\" the song is driven by superb piano playing with a slight funky feel to it. \\"Friends and Lovers\\" shows Incubus' growth and evolution and features a psychedelia sound, something I haven't heard from their past songs but fits in perfectly. The guitar arrangements on \\"Thieves\\" are incredible and deliver with nothing short of a sonic boom. \\"Switch Blade\\" is best described as edgy and fast and is one of the best songs on the album. The female singer used as a background vocalist adds a unique touch, and the sound is crisp and fresh. \\"Tomorrow's Food\\" is a great song to close out the CD. If features awesome finger picked guitars with deep, soothing lyrics leaving you wanting more. Overall this is an amazing album. Every song is good; there isn't one filler at all. I would recommend it to anyone.

B000NA28I4|2.0|Once upon a time, I blazed through this book called Eragon that I thoroughly enjoyed. I was a sophomore in high school when I discovered it and I loved on it hard, waiting with rapt attention for each succeeding novel to come out. When they decided to make a movie, I knew I would never willingly pay money to see it on the big screen so I waited for it to make it to the little one.<br /><br />The first time I watched it, I caught it about midway through the movie. Five minutes later, I was flipping channels to settle on a Lifetime Movie.<br /><br />Tonight, I decided to watch it again and was slapped in the face with why I didn't watch it the first time.<br /><br />I understand that Paolini manages to shove a wagon-load of information about the races into the first book. Elven and dragon lore, human history of the divide between Galbatorix and the Varden BLAH BLAH BLAH. I get that. But MAN. The creators of the film took the basic premise of the book and SPRINTED WITH IT. And not towards the finish line!!!!<br /><br />His interactions with Brom before he leaves his town are almost non-existant. That I could have put up with - okay, they didn't know how to fit all of that in. They completely cut out the Roran & Katrina backstory. That I raised an eyebrow at because it becomes the focal point of a book down the line and the resulting events are a key twist in what starts to separate Eragon from the rest of the human race. So I blinked and excused them with the thought 'hey maybe they just wanted a single movie'! Then my next question was where's the all important relationship with the rest of the townspeople? That goes hand in hand with the Roran & Katrina backstory. That's also gone for no reason! Ooookkkaaayyy, they really want to shrink the movie time.<br /><br />The mega morphing of Saphira on her first flight? My inner sense of outrage began to build while I sputtered some nonsense about 'ah, they need to make her grow quickly and establish that mental connection a.s.a.p.' Okay. Alright.The first flight after the Razac found him? They took the liberty of having her snatch him up on his way to find Uncle Garrow and then sort of hold on/toss him around and have an actual conversation which included \\"They'll kill you\\" and \\"You're ridiculous\\" and \\"Stupid boy\\" all in one go. Here's where I started to lose interest and gain a healthy measure of disgust for the movie.<br /><br />That. Is. Not. How. It. Happened.<br /><br />It ruined the integrity of the movie for me. She's not supposed to be coherent, Eragon is supposed to be in lots of pain, and the delay in getting to his uncle combined with the pain was a HUGE catalyst for character growth! That's the first time he's honest to goodness angry at Saphira! The rest of the movie passes in a blur of uninteresting riding scenes, tepid fighting scenes, and countryside stills. Saphira's sarcasm and Eragon's everpresent curiosity is compromised. There is no rhyme or reason explaining why the screenwriters pulled events out of thin air to insert into the plot line, or why they altered things that were pivotal to a later scene that lessened its impact. Eragon uses magic without knowing the hows and whys, gains experience out of nowhere in swordsmanship, mourns his uncle for about two and a half seconds, thinks about Arya for about the same length of time before he meets and falls in love with her, thinks about his beloved cousin Roran...NEVER, and just sort of stumbles his way in and out of nonsense for the remainder of his time on screen. Why smash the events of a book and a half into a single movie if you have simply butchered the thing? Did they even send their script to Paolini to be okayed before this entered production?<br /><br />The answer is clearly no.<br /><br />No wonder Paolini is saying 'Fu^% no!' to signing over the rights to the rest of his books! Ed Speeler (Eragon) does his best to try and even out the strange plotholes and twists and turns that the screenwriters created but he can barely keep up himself. So does Brom. Everyone else is doing too much or too little to make the audience believe what they were watching, including the dragon.<br /><br />About the only good things to say about this movie refer to the good looks of the male cast. Ed Speeler has that whole adorable thing going for him which is nice. Garret Hedlund as Murtagh is spot freaking on! His hotness ALMOST made me finish the movie and that's saying something. Fifty-five minutes was more than enough torture for me.<br /><br />This was better left as book. There is far too much lost in the translation.
0307387178|3.0|I was hoping that this book would be entirely about Chris McCandless, but a huge portion of it was about the author's own personal life, the lives of McCandless' relatives and friends, and other travelers who the author compares to McCandless. I didn't want to read about other people, I wanted Chris's story. And what we actually get of his story is fascinating and riveting. I just wish we got more of it.     I was also perplexed by how many times we got references to Chris's camera and journal, but the entire book is without photos (save one in the very beginning) and almost nothing from the journal (though we get to read a handful of postcard messages and letters). But upon further research, it seems that Chris's family plans to release another book that will include some photos and other material. Why they weren't included in this book puzzles me. I don't want to believe that the family is using this poor kid's tragic story as a money-making machine, but with multiple magazine articles, a book, a film, and another book on the way... one has to wonder. Chris, after all, wasn't especially close to his family.    I would much rather have had a book filled with photos and journal entries, than Krakauer's confusing, wandering tales that jump back and forth in time (we begin the story with Chris's death? why isn't that at the end?). The timeline of the book is so jumbled that I had trouble keeping track of what was happening, where it was, when it was.     So this book gets 3 stars from me. It was too much like a tease - giving bits of Chris's amazing story, then giving me page after page of other, unnecessary \\"stuff\\" before going back to Chris again. Whether he was a reckless idiot or an unfortunate philosopher, his story is touching and tragic.

0439023521|5.0|I began this particular journey with nothing special in mind. I've heard about The Hunger Games. While browsing Barnes and Noble and Borders, I've seen the book on the shelf sitting next to \\"Waiting for Superman\\" in the best seller aisle. I've wanted to read it. But I never got around to it.<br /><br />Then I started hearing more and more. No special details, just little blurbs here and there saying how great the book is. How excellently written this book was. How amazing this book was. But no special details were ever spoken. And I can understand why now.<br /><br />I recently received a copy in the mail. Yay! A new book for me to read! This finally gave me the motivation to read through The Hunger Games. And I am glad I did. As of now, I am anxiously awaiting the other two books so I may finish the series.<br /><br />The Hunger Games is set in the distant future after America goes berserk. What follows is a corrupt and controlling government surrounded by 13 districts. An uprising occurs and a civil war breaks out. The capitol and controlling government wins, wiping out district 13 in the process. As a reminder to the remaining 12, the Capitol holds the The Hunger Games.<br /><br />I'm not going to give any more of the story than that. Even that may be a bit much. But it's only a small piece of background information that doesn't hold much to the story other then why it exists. Ultimately why the Hunger Games exist, what they are, and how they are held is what is important.<br /><br />I fear writing any more of the story, giving small details and information, because I don't want to ruin the shock value. The author, Suzanne Collins, Paints a picture that is so utterly shocking and unthinkable. The brutality and nature of the The Hunger Games supersedes only the viciousness of what the Roman Empire was once capable of. The imagery, details, and ideas of this novel paint a graphic and grim time.<br /><br />The first pages will leave a person depressed. Never could I, myself, imagine the hardships of the main character. And then it only gets worse. I feel sad for the day that our society may ever reach this point.<br /><br />Suzanne Collins writing style is very first person. It's as blunt as a brick to the forehead. This kind of perspective is a little strong for my taste. But after reading the novel I can't see any other way of having it done. The strong first person perspective portrays the emotion of the main character perfectly. The read receives an absolute sense of her strength, hatred, worry, terror, love, and confusion. There is a strong disconnect portrayed between the main character, her followers, and the Capitol. And through the eyes of her, you get a sense of how desensitized the population of the Capitol is, and how lonely and dread-filled the remaining 12 districts are.<br /><br />The Hunger Games is a book that provokes strong and confusing emotions. You want the main character to succeed and to win. But at the same time, the acts she MUST commit are so very horrible and repulsive. You begin to feel the love and passion, the hatred and terror she feels. And the plot line will leave you riveting for more. Throughout the pages you'll be left wondering how something so horrible as the Hunger Games can exist, yet you won't be able to stop reading.<br /><br />I make the details of book out to be perceived as horrible book. Yes, the content and plot line is unthinkable. But the book is amazing. The strong first person perspective does its job precisely and exact. The author has provided an incredible story that conveys more than a little amusement. I found it extremely difficult to put down this book. After reading, I came to find out that a movie is being produced from the book. I could only think, \\"How on earth this is even possible?\\" I am curious to see the movie. And after you read the book you will understand. I do recommend this novel. It's amazing and worth every penny.character. And then it only gets worse. I feel sad for the day that our society may ever reach this point.    Suzanne Collins writing style is very first person. It's as blunt as a brick to the forehead. This kind of perspective is a little strong for my taste. But after reading the novel I can't see any other way of having it done. The strong first person perspective portrays the emotion of the main character perfectly. The read receives an absolute sense of her strength, hatred, worry, terror, love, and confusion. There is a strong disconnect portrayed between the main character, her followers, and the Capitol. And through the eyes of her, you get a sense of how desensitized the population of the Capitol is, and how lonely and dread-filled the remaining 12 districts are. But at the same time, the acts she MUST commit are so very horrible and repulsive. You begin to feel the love and passion, the hatred and terror she feels. The strong first person perspective does its job precisely and exact. The author has provided an incredible story that conveys more than a little amusement. It's amazing and worth every penny.

0525423273|5.0|Parlez-vous francais? Non? Okay, I'll do this review in English then. I absolutely loved this book and couldn't put it down. Typically I'm that way with action books, but Anna and the French Kiss was packed with all sorts of high school and relationship drama, but in a good way.    Stephanie Perkins did a great job explaining Anna's thought process throughout. I think you could hand this book to any guy and say, `See? This is how we think,' because it was dead-on with everything from Anna's overanalyzing to her obsessing over her relationship with Etienne (or St. Clair, depending on the day). It actually read to me as a diary what with all the sarcasm and sometimes snark. I also really like Anna because she isn't a typically perfect protagonist who can do no wrong; in fact, she has a lot to learn about being a friend and how she interacts with others.    Etienne is a complex character and perfect love interest. While I love the evolution of his relationship with Anna (and yes, they are utterly perfect for each other), I don't think this is a book just about a relationship; it's about friends. All of Anna's friends - at home and in France - are believable and realistic. You could probably see one of your best friends (or frenemies) in any one of these roles. They are all flawed of course, but funny, understanding, honest and they won't take your crap.    Because of that, this book didn't need any crazy plot twists or fantastical elements. It has the perfect mix of love, friendship and drama with just a hint of France. Pick it up, you'll love it.

0743270754|4.0|For many years I have enjoyed history, politics and studying leadership. \\"Team of Rivals The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln,\\" by Doris Kearns Goodwin allowed me to enjoy all of these in one book.    Team of Rivals goes far beyond just a biography of events, but delves deep into the character of Lincoln. When Lincoln began to form his Cabinet team he did not take the normal route of patronage. He had two political goals in mind. First to unite the moderate and radical factions of the Republican Party and second to select the person who had the best skills to fulfill the specific Cabinet role. With the ability to meet these two goals he was able to accomplish his two Presidential goals, reunite the nation and end slavery. The people he found were his rivals for the Republican nomination. He built a team who often disliked each other, and still had their own agendas. But Lincoln found away to bring them together as a team and successfully accomplish all four goals.    Lincoln was a very skillful and shrewd politician, but he stayed true to his beliefs and passion for our great country.    Here are a few of the leadership principals that were evident in the life of Abraham Lincoln:        Willingness to take responsibility. Even when one of his Cabinet members made an error, or even went against Lincoln's wishes, he would step up and take full responsibility without calling out the person in error.        He was not concerned with who received credit.        Lincoln could see beyond the current actions of his Cabinet members and his Union Generals and see their potential.        Lincoln was long suffering. Because he could see the true potential of others, he gave them multiple chances to rise to the occasion. Only after many failed attempts would he remove someone who was not performing well.        Lincoln stayed true to his values and principles to reunite the country and slavery. When the bloody war was finally over he worked to welcome the South back into theUnion without holding a grudge, or seeking revenge or punishment.    Goodwin also includes a lot of personal information that shows Lincoln as a master story teller, devoted husband and father. He would often use his stories to diffuse deep political tension, and drive home his point.    To me the book was a bit long (over 700 pages). Almost the 1st half of the book is a mini-biography of Lincoln and each of his primary Cabinet members. It is not until page 329 that you get to Lincoln's inauguration.     I feel that Goodwin sums up the book when she states,    \\"By calling these men to his side, Lincoln had afforded an opportunity to exercise their talents to the fullest and to share in the labor and glory of the struggle that would reunite and transform their country and secure their own places in prosperity.\\" p. 747    This a great book for any fan of Lincoln, history or politics. It is also a great guide on leadership based on values and principles held by Abraham Lincoln who lived it out during the greatest crisis of our nation.
B001AMNL2Q|5.0|As a movie buff, and a Vietnam era Veteran (graduating boot Oct. 1971) it's my opinion this is one of the very few films that show what boot camp was like before a congressmen's son died while in training and the military changed their training tactics.     As someone else mentioned in their review, somehow the suicide murder rate was over looked, but subjectively speaking, during the first weeks of boot there where allot more suicides, or being booted out of the service than people breaking down to the degree as the Leonard (Private Pyle) character did, as where all the characters. The truth is people that where as slow as his character was would have been given a General Medical Discharge after attempts such as being sent to special training with others that where slow or had other issues, restart boot, but not kept to the obvious inability to cope as his character displayed. For the most part if you kept up, you where ok, but there where those that could not deal with the shock of boot camp, or sadly where not ready for what they gotten them selfs into.    Lee Ermey obviously new his role well and played it to perfection and was another stand out, in my experience you honestly learn to respect your instructors, and after awhile, it really wasn't that bad. But this is subjective so take it for what it's worth.    Over all I felt the film drifted a little in the second half, but the performances are right on, and I don't care if it is a or isn't an anti-war film, but was thankful for the memories (good and bad), and believe it's one of the best films of its kind.

My father couldn't even wait for the shipping so he bought one at Bass Pro. I expected a higher price tag for such a great item but I was pleasantly surprised once again by amazon's low low prices. B000SEIK2S|2.0|Scalzi has a popular blog and all the social connections that matter in being a geek, so I've heard a lot of praise for Old Man's War. It has a compelling premise: 75-year-old humans are recruited to fight in a war that the recruitees know nothing about and powered by technology that does not exist on the home planet. The book slides along thanks in part to Scalzi's witty dialogue and punctual prose. The plot owes much to Starship Troopers and Scalzi admits as much in the acknowledgements. I probably won't be reading the later entries in the series. For one, the premise doesn't really tie in to the action or the climax. There's really no reason the recruits need to be old men and women isolated from the technological future brought to the present by the CDF except for that it makes for a good introduction to the universe for the reader. I was a little disappointed by that. The action was fast paced, but I don't feel there is much change in the world by the end. I can see why others like it. The story just wasn't my bag.
0312600844|1.0|I don't get all the hype over Franzen.  After the Newsweek cover last year, I read The Corrections and thought Ho-Hum.  Even if you're only going to pay attention to white males, as Newsweek did, Richard Russo is so much wittier, his characters so much more complicated.  Once we're stuck inside Patty in her third-person autobiography for 100 pages, it's inconceivable why anyone would be attracted to her.  All the characters are one-dimensional.  Even though I agree with the politics, I still felt lectured. And his editor should have said, \\"Cut at least 200 pages.\\"  The length is self-indulgent.
081297381X|5.0|I don't tend to re-read books. They stick with me pretty well, so I get bored on second readings. However, The Black Swan was both so important and so dense with information that I plan on giving it another read through before too long. Taleb's main premise is Socratic in nature: we are overconfident in what we know. We base our predictions of the future on the past which is horribly irrelevant in the case of events that have never happened before. He rails against academics in quite a pompous way that would have turned me off if he didn't seem to be so damn correct. The titular Black Swan is an event which is an outlier with extreme impact that we humans tend to give explanation to post facto as if it were predictable beforehand. He spends a lot of time defining the difference between \\"Mediocristan\\" variables - things that can be modeled by bell curves and standard operating procedure and \\"Extremistan\\" variables that are Mandlebrotian and in the realm of the Black Swan. I could try to further summarize here, but the book is too full of interesting arguments and too layered in its approach for me to do justice to it. Instead, I encourage you to pick it up. It has radical consequences for anyone who does business, makes predictions or votes. It is my Book of the Year.
0060786523|3.0|The book is fine, not amazing.  Just fine.  It is impressive in its length and breadth but I did not find it a great novel.  I'm not sorry I read it, but I wouldn't read it again.    While I am impressed with Seth's range of knowledge, I think, much like Haresh when talking about his work, he forgets that not everyone is interested in so much detail.  And there was plenty:  about parliamentary proceedings, about legal proceedings, about poems, about shoemaking... There was a lot of self-indulgence on the part of the author.    Part of the problem too is the length; as I would become engrossed in a particular story line - there are many - it would stop in favor of another, sometimes for a significant amount of pages.  Also, the multiple and complicated story lines prevented the book from achieving much depth of character.  I found that I liked many of people, but they were often one-dimensional.  Mrs. Rupa Mehra was an overly emotional over-reacter.  Over and over again.  Arun was a selfish arrogant bully.  All the time.      [Plot reveal alert:  And Lata, who had the most potential, was the biggest disappointment to me.  She went from showing some independence and spirit to, well, choosing to avoid real feelings.  And while I thought that Lata's reasoning has its merits - passion alone does not a happy marriage make - I didn't believe she actually got there herself.  In one instant she had decided H. was not for her, and then, as we got close to the end, she suddenly changes her mind.  Sure, her relationship with Kabir was complicated - so don't marry him.  Don't marry anyone yet.  That would have been more in keeping with Lata's character.  It seemed to me that the ending was chosen because it was the most convenient.  Her decision worked well for wrapping up the book - after all, if she had chosen someone else, the reader would want to know more about her married life, probably necessitating another 500 pages.  Instead, her choice left me with no interest whatsoever in her safe, comfortable life.]    Overall, I enjoyed most of the book, but it wasn't one of the greats to me.

0545259088|3.0|In Maggie Stiefvater's [[ASIN:0545259088 Forever (Wolves of Mercy Falls, Book 3)]], the final book in the Wolves of Mercy Falls trilogy, Sam is waiting for Grace to become human again as winter melts into spring. Cole is taking huge risks to try and find a cure, and Isabel continues to struggle with her brother's death. The stakes are raised when a hunt to kill the wolves is approved, and Sam, Cole, and Isabel must race against time to save Grace and the pack. With no easy solutions in sight, nothing is certain regarding who will live and love into another season.<br /><br />Like always, Stiefvater's lyrical prose impressed me with its ability to create distinct imagery and to evoke emotion. Isabel and Cole shined as characters that grow, both by themselves and together, and I found their shared moments to be the most touching. All of the characters, even those whom we're supposed to love, are shown to have significant flaws, and the story deals openly with the issue of what is forgivable and what is not. Strong themes about selfish versus selfless behavior, self-destruction and suicide, the value and worth of love, and the importance of consent and choice also ran throughout. I appreciated seeing these themes woven into the story, and I appreciated even more seeing Stiefvater note some of them in the dedication, author's note, and acknowledgments. The novel also finished with a somewhat open ending that allows readers to imagine an uncertain but hopeful future for the characters, which I found more believable than a pat ending.<br /><br />Even with all of these strong points, FOREVER didn't provide the satisfying conclusion for which I had hoped. Like in [[ASIN:0545123291 Linger (Wolves of Mercy Falls, Book 2)]], the voices of the different narrators were often not distinct, and I sometimes found myself checking the chapter headings to identify the speaker. The prose in this installment also felt too intentional: I often felt like passages were written for the mere beauty of the words, not because they represented a character's voice well. While I loved Isabel and Cole, they outshined Sam and Grace in this book, much to the detriment of the two main characters. Despite the hardships their relationship undergoes, the cautious nature in which Sam and Grace treated each other felt artificially strained. Because of this, I never reconnected to their love story. Some parts of the resolution also felt too convenient, and the werewolf pathology remained unclear. Finally, while I did appreciate aspects of the open ending, some things felt just as unresolved as they were at the end of the two previous books.<br /><br />After falling in love with the author's writing in her faerie novels, the [[ASIN:0545123275 Shiver (Wolves of Mercy Falls)]] books unfortunately never grabbed me in the same way. Despite this lack of connection with the series, I continue to be very impressed with Stiefvater's writing and her ability to connect readers to the emotions of her characters. I'm looking forward eagerly to her upcoming stand-alone novel, [[ASIN:054522490X The Scorpio Races]], to see if I can find that connection to her writing again.words, not because they represented a character's voice well.
